clean_wm_text: The assembly history of galaxies is one of the most important unsolved problems in modern astrophysics and has been extensively studied through deep surveys at different wavelengths (e.g., optical/near-infrared).

In this work, we analyzed the stellar mass assembly of over 100,000 massive galaxies selected from the VVDS-02h region, which were observed using the VIMOS spectrograph on the Very Large Telescope over a redshift range of 0 < z < 5.
We use a new technique that combines photometric redshift and spectral energy distribution fitting to derive accurate estimates of galaxy masses over such a large redshift range.
Our results show that the evolution of the average stellar mass density can be described as two main phases: i) a rapid increase before z ~ 2, followed by ii) a slower growth phase until today.
This behavior is consistent with previous research, but our data allows us to investigate in detail how the accumulation of stellar mass varies with galaxy properties such as color or morphology.
We consider an Einstein equation with a spherically symmetric solution in five dimensions, where the extra dimension is compactified on S¹/Z₂.
Most are assumed to be empty, while the material field is confined within our four-dimensional world ("brane").
We found that this model can explain the flatness of the observed galaxy rotation curves without introducing any new particles or unusual forms of energy density.
In particular, we demonstrated how the mass distribution within galaxies may be a natural consequence of spacetime geometry.

We investigated whether pulsar timing observations could detect gravitational waves by observing the Shapiro effect, which is caused by gravitational waves passing through the spacetime around the Earth and its companion star (the Sun).
We found that this method requires very precise measurements of the arrival times of pulses over many years, and therefore, under the current technological conditions, this method is not feasible.
However, we demonstrate how future radio telescopes equipped with new technologies, such as phased array feeds or digital backends, could be capable of making such measurements.
In addition, we discussed other possible methods for searching for gravitational waves using pulsar timing data.
Gravitational waves cause a time delay between the pulses emitted from different points on the surface of a rotating neutron star.
The time delays depend on the distance between these points and their positions relative to the observer's line of sight.
The most significant effects occur when the wave passes close to the Earth and its companion star.
This leads to an additional delay known as the Shapiro effect.

In 1991, 1992, 1993, and 1994, data collected by the EGRET instrument on the CGRO satellite was used to study gamma-ray emissions in the energy range from 100 MeV to 10 GeV.
The analysis was conducted in two different regions, one located at l = 0° and b = -5°, which includes the galactic center region, and the other located at l = 180° and b = +5°.
In both cases, we used the iterative maximum likelihood method to determine the flux of each source and their spectral parameters.
We found that the observed gamma-ray flux above 1 GeV has three different components contributing: a diffuse component with a power-law spectrum that extends up to about 10 GeV.
The point source located at the supermassive black hole Sgr A* has a power-law spectrum.
A nearby extended source near the center of the Milky Way, featuring a broken power-law spectrum.
We also present the results obtained from repeating the same analysis after excluding the contributions from the central part of the Milky Way.
We study the electroexcitation of nonlinear waves in a two-dimensional channel under a voltage bias applied between two parallel metal plates, with a dielectric layer interposed between them.
We indicate that different types of nonlinear waves can be excited depending on the parameters of the system (the thickness of the dielectric layer and the density of the electrons).
Specifically, we found that for certain specific values of these parameters, there exist solitary wave solutions that are similar in form to those found previously in one-dimensional systems.

The existence of this solitary wave has been experimentally verified through time-resolved optical reflectance measurements conducted at room temperature on GaAs/AlGaAs quantum well samples grown by molecular beam epitaxy.
These experiments reveal the presence of bright solitary waves propagating in the vertical direction of the applied electric field.
Their propagation speed is consistent with the theoretical predictions from numerical simulations based on the underlying equations.
The results presented here may have significant applications in semiconductor devices. Recent studies have shown that the generation of solitary waves can enhance performance characteristics.

We presented our analysis results on the impact of cosmic rays on galaxy clusters, using both cosmological hydrodynamic simulations with and without cosmic rays.

We found that at larger radii (r > 0.5Rvir), the presence of cosmic rays leads to an increase in gas temperature, which is due to the adiabatic compression of the intracluster medium (ICM) during the formation of the galaxy cluster.
The effect is more pronounced when the initial magnetic field strength is higher.

Furthermore, we found that there is a significant difference in the radial distribution of X-ray surface brightness with and without cosmic rays (CR), which can be used as an observational characteristic of their presence.
Finally, we demonstrate that the inclusion of CR has a minimal impact on global properties (such as total mass or luminosity), but it does affect the distribution of metals within the star cluster.
This work was funded by NASA under grant number NAG5-9998.

In this paper, we examine the power control issue in cellular mobile radio systems using Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA).
We consider the uplink scenario, where each user sends signals to their base station using orthogonal spreading sequences, and all users share the same frequency band.
The goal is to minimize the total transmission power while satisfying the individual quality of service constraints for each user's receiver.
In order to obtain workable results, we utilize tools from stochastic geometry, which allows us to model the positions of mobile devices and interference sources as point processes.
Our main contributions are summarized as follows.
First, we derive a closed-form expression for the interruption probability as the number of active users approaches infinity.
These expressions can be used to determine how many users can reliably communicate simultaneously over the network.
Secondly, we proposed a distributed power control scheme that can asymptotically achieve these limits under certain conditions.

Thirdly, we developed a centralized power control algorithm that ensures performance is still close to optimal, even when only partial information about channel gain or interference levels is available.
Finally, we present the simulation results and our theoretical findings.

Fullerenes are spherical molecules composed entirely of sp2 hybridized carbon, which can be arranged in various ways to form different allotropes with unique properties.
The most common is the C60 molecule (Buckminsterfullerene), but other forms such as nanotubes or graphene have also been reported.
Fullerenes were first discovered by Kroto and others, who received the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1996 for their work in this field.

In this study, we report the growth mechanism and structural characteristics of a novel carbon-based nanomaterial, which consists of an interconnected network of amorphous nanoparticles, similar to fullerenes.
These structures were self-grown under ultra-high vacuum conditions at temperatures of 600-700 °C by evaporating carbon atoms onto a silicon substrate.

We demonstrated how these new carbon nanostructures exhibit exceptional mechanical properties, with high elasticity and hardness, while having a low friction coefficient, making them ideal candidate materials for use as protective coatings against wear and corrosion.

We demonstrate how to efficiently accomplish this task using dynamic programming techniques.

Our method also allows us to maintain consistent reasoning across multiple sequential or concurrent experiments.

We present our results of the time-averaged spectrum and light curve analysis of GRB 090902B, which is one of the brightest bursts detected by the Fermi/GBM (Gamma-Ray Burst Monitor).
We found that its average spectrum can be well fitted with two blackbody functions plus a high-energy power-law component.
The temperature of each blackbody function decreases as the emission radius increases.
This behavior is consistent with the theoretically predicted relativistic outflow from the photosphere.
In addition to this thermal radiation component, we also detected non-thermal radiation above 100 MeV.

Our spectral fitting suggests that there are three distinct physical regions contributing to the observed gamma rays: 1) a photosphere-like region that produces thermal radiation; 2) an internal shock region that generates non-thermal radiation; 3) a magnetized wind region responsible for high-energy photons.
These findings provide new insights into the physics of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs).

We studied the statistical properties of Barkhausen noise generated by an Ising spin system with random fields and surface competitive interactions, using wavelet analysis on the time series produced by the model.
We found that the power spectrum of the Barkhausen noise signal can be well described by a stretched exponential function over several orders of magnitude in frequency space.

The stretching index depends on the temperature T and the magnetic field H. In particular, we demonstrate how the stretching index can serve as an indicator of the degree of disorder in the sample under study.
Finally, we discuss the possibility of extending our work to other systems that exhibit avalanche dynamics.

RMT handles statistical analysis of the eigenvalue distribution of various families of random matrices.

One of the most popular models in Random Matrix Theory (RMT) is called the Wigner ensemble. In this model, we consider an N×N Hermitian matrix \( H = H^{†} \), where the independent and identically distributed elements \( h_{ij} \) have a mean of zero and a variance of \( 1/N \).

For example, if the probability density function \( p(h) \) of each element \( h_{ij} \) decays sufficiently quickly as \( |h| \to \infty \), then conclusions can be drawn based on standard arguments.

The empirical measure µ_N of the eigenvectors of the normalized Hamiltonian H almost certainly weakly converges to a certain deterministic probability measure µ, which is defined on the unit circle T = {z ∈ C : |z| = 1}, and is referred to as the circular law.

Moreover, based on additional assumptions regarding the decay rate of p(h), the Stieltjes transform m_N(z) := E Tr(H − z^(-1)) almost surely converges pointwise to the Stieltjes transform M(z) of µ [5].

We studied the scaling behavior of two different types of surfaces: one made of high-temperature resistant glass (transparent material) and the other made of silicon dioxide (SiO2, opaque material).
The surface of SiO2 was prepared by etching with hydrofluoric acid to remove any traces of metal contamination that may have existed after the wafer was cut.
The two surfaces are then cleaned using standard cleaning procedures, followed by particle bombardment under ultra-high vacuum conditions at room temperature.

We found that when we plotted their respective roughness as a function of the number of deposited atoms per unit area, both surfaces exhibited similar scaling behavior at different angles of incidence (ranging from 0° to 60°).
However, some differences were observed in the scaling indices obtained from these two surfaces.
These results indicate that the scale behavior of these surfaces may depend not only on the chemical composition, but also strongly on other factors such as the microstructure of the substrate used.
We present the research results on the continuous radiation from the accretion disks of black hole candidates (BHCs).

We have developed an analytical model to calculate the spectra emitted by a thin optically thick accretion disk around a Schwarzschild black hole, and we have applied it to several black hole candidates with known mass functions.
The observed spectrum was well reproduced when we assumed that the inner edge of the disk is located at 6 gravitational radii.
This result indicates that the standard thin disk model can serve as a good approximation for simulating the X-ray continuous emission of these celestial bodies.

1 Introduction

In recent years, significant progress has been made in understanding the physical processes occurring near supermassive black holes (SMBH) in active galactic nuclei (AGN), quasars, and other similar systems.
These studies rely on observations of the spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of supermassive black holes in the frequency space over many years.
However, due to their enormous distances, the intrinsic brightness of most active galactic nuclei cannot be measured directly.
Conversely, indirect methods can be used, such as reflection mapping or calculating the statistical correlation of various properties of active galactic nuclei (AGN) to determine their brightness.
For example, if we know how much light passes through a certain area of interest in an active galactic nucleus (AGN), we can use simple geometric reasoning to calculate its luminosity.
Alternatively, if we know the distance to an active galactic nucleus (AGN), we can directly measure its absolute magnitude.
Unfortunately, both methods require a detailed understanding of the structure of the launch area, and this information is currently not obtainable through observation.

Therefore, in order to accurately estimate the brightness of distant active galactic nuclei (AGNs), it is necessary to develop models that can reproduce the spectral energy distribution (SED) observed in nearby active galactic nuclei.

The segmented clock is an oscillating gene regulatory network that controls the periodic formation of segments in vertebrates, such as vertebrae and ribs.

The segmented clock consists of two interlocked feedback loops with different timescales; one loop involves the periodically expressed genes Hes1-7 (Hairy/Enhancer-of-split related), while the other loop involves the genes Notch-Delta-Stat3-Gata6-8-Hes7.
In this study, we demonstrate how to combine these two circuits to utilize a mathematical model based on ordinary differential equations to produce stable limit cycles for all parameter values.
We also demonstrated how to transform it into spatial patterns by coupling the periodicity of the segmentation clock with the reaction-diffusion system generated by morphogens.
Finally, we use our results to explain why mutations in some segmental clock components lead to skeletal deformities while others do not.

Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is an important evolutionary force that can increase genetic diversity and accelerate evolution, but it also has negative impacts, such as disrupting co-adapted gene complexes or introducing harmful mutations into the recipient genome.
Through this study, we used computational models to investigate how horizontal gene transfer affects the average fitness of single-celled organisms evolving under different environmental conditions.
We found that when cells are exposed to fluctuating environments with high-intensity stress events, horizontal gene transfer (HGT) enhances average fitness.
However, if there are only slight fluctuations, horizontal gene transfer would reduce the average fitness because it introduces deleterious mutations.
Finally, in a constant environment with no external pressures, horizontal gene transfer has no effect on the average fitness.
Our results indicate that horizontal gene transfer may have played an important role in the early stages of evolution by enhancing the adaptability of life to changing environments.

The author reported the observation results using the HESS astronomical telescope array, which detected radiation with energy exceeding 1 TeV (1 tera-electronvolt) from within a 0.2-degree range of the center of the galaxy M87.
The data is consistent with theoretical predictions, suggesting that this emission should be caused by particles accelerated near the event horizon of a supermassive black hole.
This is the first time that this phenomenon has been observed outside our own galaxy, which opens up new opportunities for studying the particle acceleration processes around black holes.
A black hole is one of the most extraordinary objects known to science.
They have no surface or edges, but exist at the singularity where spacetime ends.
In addition, they exert a tremendous gravitational pull, so strong that even light cannot escape their control.
However, despite these extreme conditions, some scientists believe that matter can still accelerate to near the speed of light near the so-called "event horizon" surrounding a black hole.
Such high-energy phenomena may produce extremely energetic photons, referred to as "TeV gamma rays" - that is, tera-electronvolt photons.
These can be detected using ground-based telescopes, such as the telescopes used by the High Energy Stereoscopic System (HESS).

On April 10, 2014, astronomers working at the HESS Observatory announced that they had detected TeV gamma rays from the central region of the distant galaxy Messier 87 (M87), located about 50 million light-years from Earth.
This is the first time in history that such radiation has been observed outside of our own galaxy.
This opens up exciting possibilities for research on particle accelerators related to black holes.
To understand how this discovery was formed, we need to learn more about what happens when matter enters a black hole.
As shown in Figure 1 below, if you are standing nearby, you won't see anything particularly unusual happening until your distance from its center is less than its Schwarzschild radius.
At this point, the gravitational force becomes so strong that all forms of matter are trapped within the event horizon of the black hole.

1 Introduction  
Broad Absorption Line Quasars (BALQSOs) show blue-shifted absorption features in their emission spectra. They account for only 10%-20% of optically selected quasar samples, but may represent up to 50% of the total ultraviolet continuum flux absorbed by intervening gas clouds along the line of sight to distant quasars (Weymann et al., 1991).

In addition to serving as important detectors of the internal physical conditions of gas, Broad Absorption Line Quasars (BALQSOs) also provide information about the properties of the surrounding interstellar medium through the study of related metal line systems (for example, Weymann et al., 1979; Foltz et al., 1986; Turnshek & Savage, 1988; Hamann, 1998a, b, 1999).

However, apart from their importance as cosmological tools, our understanding of these objects has made almost no progress since they were first discovered more than 30 years ago, due to the inherent selection effects in optical surveys (see, for example, Hewett & Foltz 2003).

Recently, some authors have suggested that by using large-area near-infrared sky surveys, such as the Two Micron All Sky Survey (2MASS), many BALQSOs (broad absorption line quasars) can be discovered among the sources selected in the infrared.
We proposed a Hamiltonian formulation of general relativity incorporating matter fields on arbitrary spacetime manifolds, including both classical and quantum aspects.
The basic idea is to decompose the measurement into spatial and temporal components, as well as time dilation and offset functions.
We then introduce the conjugate momenta associated with these variables to construct the main constraints of the theory.
These constraints lead to symmetries, under which all physical quantities can remain unchanged.
In order to obtain the correct degrees of freedom, we must impose secondary constraints to eliminate non-physical modes.
Finally, we perform canonical quantization, elevating the phase space variables to operators acting on wave functions defined in the superspace (the space of all possible metrics).

We also discussed how this method can be applied to inflation models.

The flame structure examined the CH2O and CH3O free radicals using OH* chemiluminescence imaging and laser-induced fluorescence measurement techniques.

In addition, it has been observed that the presence of these additives increases the flame speed.

Finally, the effect of additive concentration on the flame structure was analyzed.

We present the numerical simulation results regarding the shallow decay stage of the X-ray light curves of GRBs, which are generated based on the interaction between the ultra-relativistic jets in the internal shock model of GRBs and their surrounding medium.
We found that this stage is mainly driven by the continuous energy injection into the leading shock of the expanding bubble formed by the jet front.

1 Introduction

In recent years, significant progress has been made in understanding the origins of Gamma-Ray Bursts (GRBs) (see Piran 2004, Zhang 2007a).

Research has found that most gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) have a relatively smooth power-law decay in their immediate afterglow, lasting for several hundred seconds. This is known as the "afterglow" phase (Costa et al., 1997; van Paradijs et al., 1997).
This phase can be explained by the synchrotron radiation emitted by electrons accelerated behind the shock wave when the ejecta collides with the surrounding medium (Sari et al. 1998).

However, some gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) exhibit a decline that is shallower than a power-law decay in the hundreds of seconds before entering the normal afterglow phase (for example, Panaitescu & Kumar 2001; Nousek et al. 2006; Liang et al. 2007; Willingale et al. 2007), which cannot be explained by the standard fireball model.

Several models have been proposed to explain these phenomena, including late central engine activity (Zhang 2007b), rejuvenated shock scenarios (Ghisellini et al. 2007), and reverse shock radiation (Kobayashi 2000; Kobayashi & Sari 2001).
Recently, Fan and Wei (2007) made suggestions regarding the shallow attenuation phase.

The purpose of this study is to develop and evaluate an algorithm that can be used to assess the uncertainty related to the dose-volume histogram (DVH) calculations performed using Monte Carlo (MC) simulation.
The proposed method is based on the concept of "uncertainty band," which is defined as the region of all possible values of a given quantity at a specified probability level.
To demonstrate its feasibility, we applied our research methods to two clinical cases involving different treatment techniques.
For each case, we used different amounts of historical data for the Monte Carlo calculations, ranging from 1x10^5 to 2x10^6.
We then compared the results obtained using the new technology with those generated using traditional methods (such as standard deviation or confidence intervals).
Our research findings indicate that the proposed method offers more accurate estimates than other commonly used methods in practice.

We present the optical spectral observations of 14 extremely high-energy peaked BL Lacertae objects (EHBLs) selected by Costamante et al. (2013).
The main objective is to study the characteristics of their host galaxies and investigate the possible differences compared to known low-energy black holes with elliptical galaxy hosts.
We found that all EHBLs have redshifts between 0.1 and 1.0, which is consistent with previous results for this type of source.
Except for one case, all sources show evidence of existence in spiral galaxies or irregular galaxies; only PKS 0537-441 shows a spectrum similar to that of elliptical galaxies.
This result suggests that there may be no significant differences between the hosts of low-energy and high-energy blazars, as previously claimed.

Keywords: variable stars, host galaxies

The Marcus-Lushnikov process is a continuous-time analog of the discrete-time Lévy walk model introduced by Montrol and Weiss in 1965, used to describe the behavior of diffusion-limited aggregation (DLA) on fractal surfaces.

The DLA (Diffusion-Limited Aggregation) growth mechanism has been observed in experiments for many years, but it was only recently that attempts have been made to mathematically model it using stochastic processes like the Marcus-Lushnikov process.
In this article, we consider two problems related to the Marcus-Lushnikov model:

First, we prove that the jump distribution of the basic Lévy process satisfies certain integrability conditions, and then the corresponding Marcus-Lushnikov process weakly converges to a Brownian motion with drift. Secondly, we show how the Marcus-Lushnikov model can be used to approximate the solution of the Smoluchowski coalescence-fragmentation equation, which describes the evolution of the particle size distribution in chemical reactions involving particle clusters.
We also discussed some connections with the Marcus-Lushnikov model and Flory's aggregation model.
We present the results of a study that investigates the characteristics and evolution of transients generated when using Lagrangian Perturbation Theory (LPT) to create initial conditions.

We found that the initial conditions based on LPT generated false large-scale power in the late stages, and increasing the number of particles used to generate these initial conditions did not suppress this phenomenon.
This effect can be mitigated by applying a low-pass filter to the evolved density field before generating new initial conditions for higher-order LPT.
However, this method does not completely eliminate all adverse effects associated with the initial conditions generated by LPT.
In addition, we demonstrate how the choice of time step for evolving initial conditions affects its accuracy.
Finally, we demonstrate that accurate initial conditions for large-scale cosmic simulations can be constructed without resorting to expensive high-resolution hydrodynamic simulations.

The first sunspot was observed for about 3 hours, during which it rotated more than 90 degrees.

This feature was previously reported as a penumbral filament, but our data did not show evidence of such a structure.

We study the distribution of the largest fragments during the fragmentation process, which is an important indicator for understanding how to optimize data transmission in networks and storage systems.

We show that this distribution can be approximated by a power law, where the exponent is \( 1 + \frac{1}{2 - p} \), with \( p \) representing the probability that two segments will merge into one when they are adjacent on the disk (the so-called "merging parameter").
This result explains why previous studies found different indices, depending on whether merging was allowed.
This approximation also allows us to derive closed-form expressions for other quantities, such as the average size of the largest fragment and its variance.
Finally, we use our results to explain some recent experimental findings about file sizes in peer-to-peer systems.
In many applications involving network data transmission and distributed storage systems, it is useful to understand how large the maximum fragment will become during the system evolution process.

For example, if a network node needs to transmit a certain amount of information within a given time limit, then understanding the proportion of total data that needs to be transmitted at any given moment may help improve performance.
Similarly, in a distributed storage system, understanding the expected size of the largest shard can determine how much space each node should reserve for storing replicas.

For small black holes with mass \( M < Mc^2 \), we prove that as \( M \) decreases, the lifetime increases exponentially.
The results were compared with those obtained from quantum field theory within the framework of curved spacetime.
The results indicate that when considering the reaction effects caused by particle generation during the evaporation process, our predictions are in very good agreement with these results.

We study the fuzzy complexity of a graph, defined as the minimum number of edges that need to be removed so that an opponent cannot distinguish between two isomorphic copies of the graph.

The fuzzy complexity of a graph G = (V, E) is defined as the minimum integer k, such that after removing at most k edges from graph G, it cannot be distinguished from another graph G' = (V', E').

1 Introduction  
Planets form through a coagulation process from dust particles (Safronov 1969; Wetherill & Stewart 1989), and then these increasingly massive bodies undergo an uncontrolled accumulation process (Lissauer 1987).
This process leads to the formation of planetary embryos, with masses ranging from 10$^{−6}$ M⊕ to several Earth masses.

If these celestial bodies accumulate enough material in a short period of time, they can further develop into larger planetesimals, or even directly form gas giants like Jupiter and Saturn (Pollack et al. 1996).
Once formed, these giant planets will open gaps in the surrounding stellar disk due to the tidal torques exerted by the planet's gravitational force (Lin & Papaloizou 1986).
Therefore, the remaining material in this gap will be quickly removed by viscous effects, leading to the rapid inward Type II migration of the planet (Ward 1997; Tanaka et al. 2002).

The observed distribution of exoplanets shows a wide variety of orbital configurations, ranging from circular orbits around sun-like stars to highly eccentric orbits around low-mass stars (see, for example, Marcy et al. We report the generation of an unprecedented broadband spectrum (>10 THz) using a novel optical fiber based on microstructured fiber, which has a suspended core surrounded by air holes filled with liquid.
The suspended core optical fiber supports two guided wave modes, which are confined in different regions of its length.

A mode propagates in the central region of the optical fiber, where it experiences strong confinement due to the high refractive index contrast between silica glass and air; this results in a large effective nonlinearity.
Another mode propagates to the central region of the suspended core, where it experiences only weak refractive index guidance.
This results in both modes having low losses over a wide wavelength range.
We demonstrate through experiments that when pumped at 1.55 micrometers, these two modes can be effectively coupled together via stimulated Raman scattering.

The variable star single observation project is an open-source software package used for astronomical data analysis.
It was developed by members of the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics (CfA) in collaboration with researchers from other institutions around the world.

The goal of this project is to provide a single tool that can be used to analyze all types of astronomical datasets, including photometric time series, spectral observations, images, and more, utilizing cutting-edge techniques such as image subtraction, cross-correlation, period-finding algorithms, and spectral line fitting.
The software is released under the GNU General Public License version 3.0 and can be found on GitHub: http://github.com/VariableStar/one-shot-astro.
One Shot Astro includes several tools that are very useful for quickly and efficiently analyzing large amounts of astronomical data.

These include one-shot-datacleaner, which performs automatic quality control checks on raw data files; one-shot-mosaic, which creates mosaic images from multiple dithered exposures; one-shot-astrometry, which determines astrometric solutions for a single frame or a whole mosaic image; one-shot-photometry, which measures the flux and/or magnitudes of stars in the field of view; one-shot-pipeline, which automates the process of combining these different tasks into a pipeline; and one-shot-wikimapia, which allows users to create custom sky maps based on their own object catalog.

In addition to these core packages, there are many additional modules available through the one-shot-astro repository. These modules allow users to perform more specialized analyses, such as: one-shot-catalog, which accesses various astrophysical databases through SQL queries; and one-shot-fastphot, which uses machine learning methods to measure stars.

We study the electrodynamic properties of Josephson vortices (JVs) in high-temperature superconductors by numerically solving the time-dependent Ginzburg-Landau equations with an external magnetic field and current density.

The speed of the joint venture company linearly increases with the applied voltage at lower voltages, but saturates at higher voltages due to the pinning effect.

We analyzed the chemical equilibrium and non-equilibrium processes occurring in the atmospheres of sub-stellar mass objects (SMBOs).

We have developed a new method to calculate the deviation from chemical equilibrium, based on the assumption that at any given point in the atmosphere, all species are in a state of local thermodynamic equilibrium with each other.
This method allows us to calculate the abundance of different molecular species at the height of the photosphere.
The results indicate that significant chemical equilibrium deviations may exist even when the gas temperature is much higher than the dust temperature.
In particular, we found that the concentration of carbon monoxide may be several orders of magnitude lower than the abundance predicted by the chemical equilibrium model.
These findings suggest that possible non-equilibrium effects should be considered when interpreting SMBO observational spectra.
Keywords: Chemical equilibrium; dust particles; local thermodynamic equilibrium.
We reported the measurement and analysis of the diffusion coefficients of probe molecules embedded in polymer solutions using optical techniques.
The experiment used two different types of probes: fluorescently labeled polystyrene spheres (PS) and dye-doped polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA).
We found that PS and PMMA exhibit abnormal sub-diffusion behavior at low concentrations, while at high concentrations, they show normal diffusion behavior.
In addition to measuring the change of mean squared displacement over time, we also measure the displacement distribution of multiple particles simultaneously.
This enables us to extract information about the fundamental dynamics, which cannot be achieved by merely observing the mean square displacement (MSD) curve of the ensemble average.

By fitting our data to an appropriate model, we are able to determine the concentration dependence of the diffusion coefficient D0 and to describe the exponent α that characterizes the power-law decay of the probability density function P(Δr).
Our results show good consistency with theoretical and experimental results compared to predictions based on the general Langevin equation (GLE).

These findings indicate that optical methods can be used to study complex systems, such as concentrated polymer solutions, where traditional light scattering techniques may fail due to multiple scattering effects.

This study is dedicated to investigating certain properties of curves in P^3 that have exceptional cutting planes, namely that there exists a line that intersects the curve at two points without passing through any other points on the curve.
We provided the necessary conditions for the curve to have a special cutting plane (Proposition 1).
Then we prove that if a curve has a particular type of intersecting plane, it lies on a quadric surface (Theorem 2).
Finally, using this result, we demonstrate how to construct all possible families of curves with special tangent planes through their associated linear systems (Theorem 3-7).
Keywords: curve, cutting plane, quadratic surface.

We presented new high-resolution (0.5 arcsecond) radio continuum observations at 1.4 GHz and 4.8 GHz using the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA).

These data are combined to generate images of the Stokes parameters I, Q, U, and V, which allows us to study the total intensity radiation and linear polarization characteristics on the surface of this nearby spiral galaxy.
We found that the polarized emission is concentrated in the brightest area of the disk, where its value reaches about 8%.
Through our research, we discovered significant circularly polarized radiation associated with two supernova remnants located near the center of the Milky Way.
This work represents an important step forward in understanding the magnetic field structure on the scale of kiloparsecs within the Milky Way.
It also provides valuable information for future research aimed at studying the propagation process of cosmic rays through the galactic disk.
Keywords: Radio Astronomy, Galaxy Evolution, Magnetic Field, Polarization

We present multi-epoch radial velocity (RV) observations of four late-type M dwarfs and three brown dwarf candidates obtained using the High Accuracy Radial velocity Planet Searcher (HARPS). The spectral types of these objects range from M3V to M8V.
We found no evidence of RV changes exceeding about 1 m/s among these targets, with timescales of up to several years.
These results are consistent with previous studies, which found almost no evidence for the existence of giant planets around low-quality stars and substellar objects.
The lack of detectable changes in radio velocity may be due to the companion star's smaller mass and/or radius, which is expected if such companions exist.
However, we cannot rule out the possibility that certain targets may exist in orbits with periods that exceed the detection range of our current dataset around Earth-mass planets.
In the future, high-precision radial velocity measurements will be needed to determine whether such planets actually exist.
We present new near-infrared (NIR) observational data obtained using the Subaru Telescope, focusing on the radio-loud elliptical galaxy NGC 4261.
The near-infrared image shows that there is an extended dust disk around the core of this galaxy.
We found that the isophotes are well fitted by a de Vaucouleurs profile plus an exponential component at large radii.
This suggests that there may be two factors influencing the surface brightness distribution: one related to the halo/disk system, and the other related to the dust disk.
Through addition, we detected a faint annular structure surrounding the central area.
These results suggest that the dust disk is likely formed through tidal interactions between the primary galaxy and the secondary galaxy.
Our analysis also indicates that within the innermost 100 seconds of the light travel time radius, the dust mass is approximately 1.5 x 10^6 solar masses.
If we assume that the ratio of dust to gas is similar to that of the Milky Way, then the total gas mass would be 5 x 10^8 M_sol.
We reported the discovery of massive outflows (with a speed of 1000 kilometers per second) in two post-starburst galaxies, which are considered to be the ancestors of modern elliptical galaxies.
These observations were conducted using Subaru/FOCAS and VLT/VIMOS, utilizing near-infrared spectra to cover the optical emission lines in the rest frame of these objects at a redshift of 0.6.
We found that both galaxies have a strong [O III] 5007Å/Hβ ratio, indicating their high ionization parameters.
Through addition, we detected a high-velocity blue-shifted component in the Hα line profile, as well as its broad tail in the Hα line profile.
The results indicate the presence of energy ion outflows driven by active galactic nuclei and/or supernova activity.
This work has received research funding from the Japanese Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology (Grant Number: 20540230).
Keywords: emission line galaxies, galaxy evolution, nearby galaxies

We propose an extension to the classical lubrication theory that takes into account the effect of shear thinning on fluid viscosity and friction coefficient, assuming that they are only functions of local pressure.

The generated model is used to study the effect of non-Newtonian rheology on the electrodynamic behavior (EHD) in circular contact between two elastic solids with different surface roughness under pure rolling conditions.

We demonstrated that the presence of shear thinning leads to significant changes in the predicted bearing capacity and the distribution of normal stress within the contact area, compared to the results obtained using a Newtonian fluid model.
Specifically, we found that when the fluid exhibits strong shear-thinning characteristics, the maximum value of the dimensionless pressure significantly increases.
Moreover, our results indicate that considering the shear thinning effect can significantly reduce the magnitude of the dimensionless tangential stress at the centerline of the contact area.
Finally, it should be noted that the proposed theoretical framework can also be used to study other important phenomena, such as thermal effects or mixed lubrication states.
We present new maps of the interstellar SiO (v=1, v=2) maser source surrounding the Mira variable star R Leo, obtained through very long baseline array observations at 22 GHz and 43 GHz.
The observation was conducted on September 24, 2004, using all ten antennas that were available for VLBA operations at that time.

We detected two different groups of microwave emitters: one group is located near the star position determined by optical astrometry; the other group is located about 0.5 arcseconds southwest of this position.
These two groups are associated with the extended bipolar structures observed in the previous single-disk observations.
This structure is interpreted as a shell-like envelope surrounding the central star.
Our results indicate that the two groups of excited microwave amplifiers (masers) trace different parts of this shell-like structure.
In addition, we found evidence suggesting the existence of a third component, which may be related to the presence of accompanying objects.

In this work, we propose an evolutionary neural gas model for input classification and clustering in self-organizing networks.
The proposed algorithm is based on the concept that each neuron can be viewed as a cluster center with its own weight vector.
In addition to updating weights according to standard NG learning rules, neurons are also allowed to evolve by applying genetic operators such as crossover and mutation.

Our experiments conducted on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms other state-of-the-art algorithms, including Self-Organizing Maps (SOM), Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN), and Evolutionary Background Graph (EBG).
Finally, we demonstrate how the proposed method can be used to solve real-world problems, such as text classification and image segmentation.
Keywords: evolutionary computation, self-organizing networks, clustering, genetic algorithms, text classification, image segmentation.

We present an analytical result aimed at determining the rates, masses, spins, and brightnesses of intermediate mass ratio inspiral (IMRI) events that can be detected by advanced gravitational wave detectors such as advanced LIGO.
We use Monte Carlo simulations to generate intrabinary shock waves in galactic binaries that are consistent with current observations of double pulsars and X-ray binaries.
The simulation system evolves through three stages: the separation stage, the Roche lobe overflow stage, and the common envelope stage.
In our simulation, we assume that all stars have solar metallicity and an initial rotation period of 10 days.
When generating each system, we use the stationary phase approximation to calculate its signal-to-noise ratio.
We found that within a range of 100 Mpc, there will be approximately one event per year with a signal-to-noise ratio greater than 8.
This is comparable to the expected merger rate of double neutron stars.
However, unlike double neutron star merger events that occur at high redshifts, the majority of IMRI events should be detected nearby.

We reported the sporadic meteors observed in August 2004 using the Suprime-Cam installed on the Subaru telescope.
The total number of detected meteor events is approximately 12,000, and their distribution in the sky closely matches the expected sporadic meteor distribution.
We also discovered some interesting features, such as the gathering around bright stars (possibly due to fragmentation) and an excess of faint meteors near the ecliptic plane.
These results may help to understand the physical processes involved in the formation of meteor streams.

In August 2004, we observed sporadic meteors during the active period of the Perseid meteor shower, using the Suprime-Cam mounted at the Cassegrain focus of the 8-meter Subaru telescope.
Our program automatically detects moving objects in images captured every 20 seconds, detecting about 12,000 meteor events.
Their spatial distribution is in good agreement with the distribution of meteors predicted theoretically by the orbital elements obtained from radar observations.
Some interesting features have also been observed; for example, the clustering around bright stars may be due to fragmentation or an excess of faint meteoroids near the ecliptic.

The main objective of this work is to study the effect of different types of initial conditions on the evolution of density perturbations in an expanding universe with a positive cosmological constant (dark energy).

We used two methods to numerically solve the Einstein equations coupled with matter fields: one is the standard method based on expanding the metric tensor in terms of spherical harmonic functions; the other is a new method we developed, which uses an expansion of the metric in terms of Chebyshev polynomials.

In these two scenarios, we considered three types of initial conditions: Gaussian random fields generated using the Zel'dovich approximation, Gaussian random fields generated using the fast Fourier transform algorithm, and white noise.
Our results show that all these models provided similar predictions when evolved to a redshift of z = 0.5.
However, there were some differences between them in the early stages.

These differences can be explained as follows: the fluctuations predicted by the Zel'dovich model are larger because it does not take into account the pressure term in the fluid equations; the white noise model produces smaller fluctuations due to its statistical properties; finally, the Gaussian random field obtained through the fast Fourier transform algorithm predicts intermediate values.
This result indicates that the choice of initial conditions may significantly affect the final value of the primordial density fluctuation power spectrum predicted by inflationary theory.

We proposed a set of equations that describe the transient enhanced diffusion (TED) process in shallow implant layers, which is essential for understanding and controlling doping profiles in semiconductor device manufacturing.
The model takes into account the impact of lattice damage on TED, as well as the effect of interstitial atoms generated by the implantation itself.
We demonstrate that this simple model can explain many experimental observations, including the dependence of TED on dose rate, annealing temperature, and annealing time.
Finally, we use our model to predict the evolution of the doping profile under different annealing conditions.

Transient Enhanced Diffusion (TED), which refers to the redistribution of dopants caused by rapid thermal annealing (RTA) following high-energy injection, has been extensively studied over the past twenty years [1].

The widely accepted view today is that the primary driving force behind the Thermal Expansion Diffusion (TED) effect is due to point defects caused by implantation, although other mechanisms, such as vacancy aggregation, may also play an important role.
The most commonly used TED simulation model assumes that all excess interstitial atoms produced by implantation are stationary at room temperature.

We reported the temporal evolution of the step fluctuations on Cu(111) and Ag(111) under electromigration conditions.
These experiments were conducted using scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), a technology that allows for the direct observation of atomic-level processes on surfaces.
We found that during the mass transfer process along the step induced by the electric current, the edges of the step fluctuate dramatically over time.
The characteristics of these fluctuations are that they exhibit exponential growth, and then reach saturation in about one hour.
In addition to this general behavior, we observed different types of fluctuations depending on the applied voltage and temperature.
For low voltage and temperatures below 300 K, the fluctuations exhibit a sawtooth shape, indicating periodic changes between two states.
For high voltages or temperatures above 400 K, the fluctuations become more irregular, but still show a certain periodicity.
Finally, no regular pattern was observed at high voltage and a temperature of about 500 K.
Our results indicate that these fluctuations can be explained as a result of competition between diffusion current and drift current.

The performance evaluation of Object-Oriented Databases (OODBs) is an important issue in database research and development. However, due to the numerous factors affecting their performance, this evaluation work has always been quite challenging.
According to this study, we propose VOODB as a universal discrete event stochastic simulation model for evaluating the performance of object databases.
The proposed model can be used with any object-oriented database (OODB) system by simply changing its configuration parameters.
We have implemented our model using Visual Basic 6.0 on the Windows NT 4.0 platform.
In order to assess the effectiveness of our model, we conducted experiments on two different object database systems: O2 and ObjectStore.
Our experimental results indicate that our model can accurately estimate the response time of two object-oriented database systems under various workloads.
Keywords: performance evaluation, database system, object-oriented database system, discrete event simulation, response time prediction.

We presented our research findings on the potential existence of stable, Earth-like planets around the star Gliese 581, located approximately 20 light-years away from Earth.
We conducted numerical simulations of three types of Earth-like planets with masses ranging from 1 to 10 times that of Earth (1-10 M⊕) under different orbital configurations.
Our calculations indicate that all these systems are dynamically stable over a timescale of more than 100 million years.
The most massive planet has an eccentric orbit with an eccentricity of e = 0.2, and its periapsis distance ranges between 0.05 AU and 0.15 AU, depending on the initial conditions used.
This planet can be considered a hot Jupiter type planet because it orbits very close to its host star.
However, we found another region where two or more Earth-like planets can stably exist.
In this region, there may exist a super-Earth type planet with a mass greater than 5 times that of Earth (5M⊕) but less than 8 times that of Earth (8M⊕).

The WiFeS instrument is an integral field spectrograph on the 2.3-meter telescope at the Siding Spring Observatory of the Australian National University.
Since 2005, it has been operating with the aim of providing high-quality spectral analysis across a wide wavelength range with minimal overhead.

The WiFeS instrument consists of two cameras, which are mounted on a common base located within a vacuum chamber. The vacuum chamber is connected to the Cassegrain focus of the 2.3-meter telescope at the Australian National University.
Each camera contains a lens array that can generate a set of images on its focal plane.
These images can be merged into a single data cube using the software developed by Dopita et al. (2007).
This data cube provides information about the spatial position and wavelength of each line of sight as it passes through the object.

In addition to this capability, WiFeS also offers several other advantages, including: - High throughput due to the use of a dichroic beam splitter and fiber coupling between the lens and the detector.
Flexible observation modes, ranging from fully automated observation to manual control via a remote desktop interface.
Quickly reading the time allows multiple targets to be observed simultaneously, or rapidly switching between different targets during nighttime observation.
Low maintenance requirements, as it does not require any moving parts inside the vacuum housing.
The excellent stability is due to the design of the optical platform and the thermal isolation provided by the vacuum chamber.
The large-format detector array can still provide excellent signal-to-noise ratio under poor observation conditions.
Reliable mechanical design ensures long-term stability.

The Catalog Archive and Transmission System (CATS) is an astronomical data archive established in 1988 by the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan (NAOJ).

We analyzed the worst-case time complexity of inserting n elements into a binary search tree using the Fibonacci heap data structure, which is based on the so-called "Yang-Fibonacci insertion."

We prove that the algorithm has a worst-case running time of O(n log n), thus improving upon the previous results by Chan et al., who showed that executing these operations in the worst case requires at least Ω(n²/³) time.
The main idea of our proof is to use amortized analysis techniques to limit the number of times the size of the heap is updated at each step of the algorithm.
This allows us to demonstrate that the total cost of all steps is bounded by O(n log n).
In addition, we also provide experimental evidence that our theoretical bounds are tight within a constant factor.
Introduction: The Fibonacci heap data structure was proposed by Fredman and Tarjan.
In their work on efficient algorithms for finding minimum spanning trees (MSTs), shortest paths, and other related problems.
It consists of a rooted binary tree, where each node has two additional fields: a parent pointer and a level value.
Each node stores pointers to its left and right child nodes; however, unlike a regular binary tree, any given node can store multiple nodes with the same key value.

Each node maintains a counter called "rank," which indicates how many keys less than or equal to the key at the current node exist under this node; if there are no such keys, the value of the rank field is zero.

We analyzed users' attention to tags and resources in the collaborative tagging community based on three years of data collected from Delicious.com (2005-2007).
We found that users' attention is highly inclined towards popular tags and resources; only about 0.1% of tags are used more than once, and less than 1% of resources receive more than one bookmark.
The distribution of user attention follows Zipf's law for both labels and resources.

In addition, we explain that this bias can be attributed to two factors: 1) popularity bias - most users tend to use labels or resources they have seen before; 2) social influence - people tend to follow others who share similar interests.

BiFeO3 is an antiferromagnetic insulator with a high Néel temperature (TC = 1103 K), which exhibits ferroelectric properties at room temperature under doping or pressure conditions.

Here, we report observations of spontaneous magnetization M(T) and polarization P(E) existing simultaneously over a wide temperature range up to 300K in pure BiFeO3 single crystals grown by the molten method.
The results show that below TC, M(T) and P(E) are almost independent of each other, but above TC, they begin to decline rapidly.
We also found that the size of M(T) decreases faster than the size of P(E).
These observations indicate that there is a strong coupling between spin and lattice degrees of freedom in this material.

1. Introduction  
Supermassive black holes are located at the centers of most massive galaxies.
Their growth is believed to be driven by gas inflows caused by gravitational torques generated during galaxy mergers and/or interactions (Barnes & Hernquist 1996; Hopkins et al. 2006).
However, it is currently unclear what will happen after this fuel supply is depleted.

One possibility is that black holes continue to grow through radiatively inefficient accretion flows (Narayan & Yi 1994), which can produce powerful winds and jets, thereby driving large-scale outflows into the surrounding interstellar medium (ISM) (Silk & Rees 1998; Di Matteo et al. 2005).

Another possibility is that when the interstellar medium becomes too hot to effectively cool, the black hole becomes dormant (Bower et al. 2006; Croton et al. 2006) until another merger event triggers new activity.
Understanding the mechanisms that suppress black hole growth will help us understand why some galaxies have massive black holes, while others do not.

We demonstrate the first discovery of cosmic rays within fossil radio plasma bubbles, utilizing deep Shen K. X-ray observations and VLA radio data of Abell 2052 (z = 0.0395).
This bubble is located at the center of an elliptical galaxy, where a prominent dust lane extends into its core.

We find that the radius of this bubble is about 40 kiloparsecs, and it contains hot gas with a temperature of about 1 keV. If the bubble is filled with shock-heated interstellar medium, this temperature is significantly lower than expected.

We believe that this bubble is filled with relativistic particles accelerated by shock waves, which are generated by the interactions with the surrounding medium during the formation process of the central galaxy.
These particles are responsible for the synchrotron radiation emission observed on a large scale around the bubbles.

In addition, we detected the diffusion of soft X-rays extending beyond the edge of the bubble, which may be due to heat conduction or the mixing of the bubble with the surrounding intracluster medium (ICM).
We propose an algorithm to find optimal hierarchical descriptors (OHDs) that can be used as fingerprints in complex networks, such as social and biological systems.
OHDs represent network structures at different levels of granularity using a tree-like structure, where nodes represent sub-networks or clusters.

We study how the Galactic disk responds to the tidal forces exerted by dark matter halos and interstellar gas filaments, resulting in deformation, using high-resolution cosmological simulations that include radiative cooling and star formation.
We found that a majority (>80%) of the simulated galaxies exhibit significant distortions at z = 0.
As the mass of galaxies decreases, the amplitude of distortion increases; however, for massive galaxies, it is independent of redshift.
The distortion amplitude is usually less than 10 milliarcseconds, which is in good agreement with the observational results.
Our results indicate that the majority of the observed distortions can be explained by the influence of external gravitational torques on the galaxy disk.
This suggests that there may not be an internal mechanism within the galaxy disk that causes the distortion.

Finally, we demonstrated that our model predicts the correlation between the direction of distortion and the angular momentum vector of the host halo.

In recent years, there has been increasing attention to non-equilibrium phenomena, such as the relaxation processes after rapid changes in external parameters [1], aging [2], and glass behavior [3], as they play important roles not only in physics but also in biology [4].
Among these topics, the dynamical Ising model is one of the most commonly used models to study non-equilibrium properties.
It describes the time evolution of the spin variables S_i(t) (i=1, ..., N) on a regular lattice under the influence of thermal fluctuations.
Here, t represents the number of Monte Carlo steps (MCS/s) at each position.
In each step, each spin interacts with its nearest neighbors by exchanging interaction \( J_{ij} \).
Then it performs flipping based on the Metropolis algorithm.

If \( e^{-\frac{S_{ij}}{k_B T}} \) is greater than a random number between 0 and 1, then flip \( S_j \); otherwise, keep \( S_j \) unchanged, where \( k_B \) is the Boltzmann constant and \( T \) is the absolute temperature.
The process continues until equilibrium is reached or other criteria are met [8].

We present the optical and near-infrared photometric data for Supernova 2006bp, which was discovered by amateur astronomer Brian Pucket on September 24, 2006, in NGC 6946 (Pucket et al., 2007).
This supernova is located at an unusually distant position in its host galaxy, with a recession speed of approximately 1000 kilometers per second.
We found that the light curve can be well fitted by a model consisting of three components: shock emission radiation, luminosity driven by radioactive decay, and dust extinction.

We present new results regarding the tidal tails around interacting galaxies, obtained from deep optical images taken with the Hubble Space Telescope/Advanced Camera for Surveys (HST/ACS), focusing on two areas: GEMS (Galaxy Evolution from Morphology and Spectral Energy Distribution) and GOODS (Great Observatories Origins Deep Survey).
We found that about half of the interactions show distinct tidal features, such as bridge-like or tail-like structures.

By adding, we identify the star formation regions in the tail by measuring their ultraviolet-optical colors.
About one third of the galaxies in our sample show strong star formation activity at distances of at least 1 kiloparsec from the center.
These starburst regions are found only in systems where the component masses are similar, differing by no more than a factor of three.
This indicates that these interactions have triggered star formation on a large scale.
Finally, we compare the characteristics of tidal tails at different interaction stages.

We study the dynamics of interacting superluminal fields in a spatially flat Friedmann-Robertson-Walker universe with zero spatial curvature, and we solve the equations of motion using numerical methods.

We found that the process of energy density evolution is divided into two distinct stages; one stage is dominated by the kinetic energy of the field, while the other stage is dominated by its potential energy.
The transition between these stages occurs when the Hubble parameter is comparable to the mass scale associated with the interaction term.
During this transitional period, we observe that the Hubble parameter and the energy densities of various individual fields exhibit oscillatory behavior.
In addition, we found that the rate at which the total energy density decreases is slower than when there is only one component present (that is, a single fast particle or a single scalar field).
Finally, we demonstrate how our results can be used to build a viable inflation model.
We consider a model consisting of a scalar field coupled to another scalar field through a quartic self-interaction term.
Using numerical techniques, we study the time evolution of various quantities, such as the Hubble parameter, the energy density of each field individually, and the total energy density.
Our analysis revealed several interesting features, including the emergence of a transition region where the Hubble parameter becomes comparable.
We report on the first integrated optical method for mid-infrared (MIR) laser beam elimination based on silicon-on-insulator technology and suspended core optical fibers.
The experimental setup includes two fiber-coupled mid-infrared lasers, with each laser used for one arm of the Michelson interferometer.
A pair of hanging core fibers is used to couple the output beam into a 2x2 multimode interferometric coupler (MMI).
To achieve a high extinction ratio for this MMI-based beam splitter, we employed a novel design that incorporates a conical region at its input port.
We achieved a maximum extinction ratio of over 40 dB by adjusting the phase difference between the two arms of the interferometer.
This value corresponds to a minimum intensity contrast of 1e-10, which is sufficient for most applications, such as space telescopes or free space optical communication systems.
Finally, we demonstrated how to optimize coupling efficiency through suspended-core optical fibers, thereby further enhancing performance.

These results provide new insights into the structure of the vacuum moduli space in string theory.

The magnesium silicate mineral (perovskite) has been studied using first-principles calculations and a semi-empirical P-V-T equation of state (EOS).

The calculation results indicate that compared to other oxides, MgSiO3 perovskite has a higher bulk modulus, lower compressibility, a large volume expansion coefficient at high temperatures, and smaller thermal expansion.
These characteristics are very important for understanding geophysical phenomena such as earthquakes and volcanic activity.
In addition to these physical properties, we also used density functional theory (DFT) methods to study the electronic structure of MgSiO3 perovskite.
We found that there is charge transfer between Si4+ ions and O2- ions, which leads to the formation of Si-O bonds.
The charge transfer causes changes in the bond lengths and bond angles of the Si-O-Si network.
Finally, we discussed the effect of oxygen vacancies on the structural stability of MgSiO3 perovskite.

We studied the effects of decoherence on quantum simulations of one-dimensional strongly correlated systems, focusing on scenarios with a large number of particles and where the Hilbert space grows exponentially with the number of particles.

We have shown that for certain classes of Hamiltonians, it is indeed possible to perform efficient numerical calculations using tensor network methods, even when considering the effects of decoherence.
Specifically, we consider two different types of errors that can be simulated by adding additional terms to the Hamiltonian that describes the evolution of the system.
The first type of error corresponds to localized fluctuations at individual energy levels, while the second type of error describes overall fluctuations that affect all positions.
For these two cases, we found that the resulting effective dynamics can still be described effectively within the same class of tensor networks as before.
This enables us to accurately calculate the time dependence of observable quantities such as correlation functions or entanglement entropy, despite the presence of noise.

We study the global structure and causal properties of (2 + 1)-dimensional Einstein spaces with a non-negative cosmological constant. These spaces are locally conformally flat but are not conformally equivalent to Minkowskian spacetime globally.
We prove that, according to their global structure, these spaces can be divided into three types, as follows:
Type I: Universal coverage of the same embryo in R × S².
Type II: A universal covering with infinitely many ends.
Type III: Universal coverage is compact.

Specifically, we prove that if the spacetime is of type I or II and contains an incomplete null geodesic segment with endpoints that have different values of the affine parameter along the geodesic, then this spacetime admits closed timelike curves.

For the application, we construct explicit metrics in open subsets of the hyperbolic plane H², the complex projective line CP¹, and the 3-sphere S³, providing examples of complete solutions for each type.
Keywords: global structure, causal relationship, closed temporal curve.

We analyzed the expected cosmic neutrino flux from different sources of cosmic rays and propagation models in IceCube, including the latest results from the anisotropy measurements of the PAMELA and AMS-02 experiments.

Especially, we found that the observed anisotropy is consistent with predictions based on conventional astrophysical acceleration mechanisms only when there is a very steep injection spectrum at the source (spectrum index less than -2).
This is inconsistent with the observations of other messengers, such as gamma rays or radio waves.

If we consider more complex particle physics processes, such as the decay of dark matter particles, it is possible to explain the observed anisotropy and cosmic ray spectrum without violating any observational constraints.
However, this scenario requires fine-tuning of parameters, which makes it less appealing than traditional astrophysical explanations.

The double heap selection algorithm is an efficient method for selecting the k-th smallest element from a set S containing n elements.

In this paper, we present some new results about the DualHeap algorithm, which reveal its efficiency and inherent parallelism.

The implementation does not require additional space beyond what is needed for the input data itself, making it very suitable for modern storage devices, such as flash memory or hard drives. We outline the latest advances in understanding quantum critical phenomena that go beyond the standard Landau-Ginzburg-Wilson framework, with a focus on fermionic systems with strong electronic correlations and Mott insulating states.

We discuss how these new ideas can be applied to understanding the unconventional superconductivity observed in many strongly correlated materials, such as high-temperature superconducting cuprates, iron-based compounds, heavy fermions, and organic conductors, which exhibit non-Fermi liquid characteristics at low temperatures.
In particular, we can focus our attention on the recently proposed concept of "multicriticality" to describe the phase diagram of these complex materials near their quantum critical points (QCPs).

These solutions may have interesting applications in astrophysics.

We present the first results of clustering measurements of luminous red galaxies (LRGs) obtained using the AAOmega multi-object spectrograph at the Anglo-Australian Observatory, within the redshift range of 0.5 < z < 0.8.

1 Introduction  
Recent studies have shown that luminous red galaxies (hereinafter referred to as LRGs), selected by their optical colors or near-infrared brightness, provide a powerful tool for detecting large-scale structures at high redshift (e.g., Eisenstein et al. 2001; Wake et al. 2006; Padmanabhan et al. 2007; Blake et al. 2008; Ross et al. 2008).
Their high brightness means they can be effectively detected even at relatively low redshifts, and their red color makes them easy to identify spectroscopically.
They are often located in huge halos of dark matter, which slowly evolve over cosmic timescales, making them useful tracers of the underlying mass distribution.

Therefore, they provide a unique opportunity to study the growth of structures and the nature of dark energy that drives their accelerated expansion (for example, see Percival & White 2009 for a review).

Here, we report the first measurement of the spatial clustering properties of Luminous Red Galaxies (LRGs) using data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) (York et al. 2000) and the Two-Degree Field Galaxy Redshift Survey (2dFGRS) (Colless et al.) within the redshift range of 0 < z < 0.8.

clean_wm_text: We proposed an algorithm that efficiently creates and propagates order in a spin chain by using geodesic paths on a graph that represents spins.

The algorithm is based on the following observation: if we treat two adjacent sites as nodes in a graph, then the probability distribution of all possible states of these two sites can be represented by a weighted edge between them.
We demonstrate how to leverage this representation to create ordered regions in the chain using only local information from the state of each site.

In particular, our method allows us to find the optimal configuration of the system at low temperatures (where thermal fluctuations are minimal) without the need to explore the entire configuration space.
This makes it possible to study systems for which precise calculations would become intractable if their sizes were not taken into consideration.
Our results indicate that the proposed method can provide accurate predictions even when applied to relatively short chains.
Finally, we discussed some extensions of the proposed concepts that could lead to further improvements in efficiency.
Introduction: Many physical phenomena, such as magnetism or phase transitions, occur due to the collective behavior of many interacting particles.
For example, magnetic ordering in solids occurs because individual atoms strongly interact with each other through their magnetic moments.
Similarly, liquid helium exhibits superfluidity below its critical temperature \( T_c = 2.17 \, K \) because pairs of helium-4 atoms form tightly bound bosons, known as Cooper pairs.
These examples indicate that understanding collective behavior requires studying a large number of interacting particles rather than individual isolated particles.
However, simulating the macroscopic properties of complex systems composed of many interacting elements remains one of the most challenging problems in computational physics today.

Indeed, although the microscopic interactions between individual particles can usually be accurately described by quantum mechanics, the macroscopic properties of large numbers of particles often involve approximations that cannot capture the subtle effects arising from the correlations between different parts of the system.
Therefore, approximate methods such as Monte Carlo sampling are commonly used for numerical simulations of large-scale models of real-world systems. [1]
Unfortunately, when these methods are used to simulate systems containing millions of elements, their computational cost is very high.
We study the cosmological evolution in modified Gauss-Bonnet gravity, which is an extension of general relativity that includes higher-order curvature corrections.
We found that this theory can be formulated as a scalar-tensor theory with two additional degrees of freedom, and we have demonstrated how it fits into the category of Horndeski theory.
In particular, we derived the field equations of the background universe and the linear perturbation equations around flat spacetime.
The resulting differential equation system has been solved numerically using standard techniques.
Our results indicate that the model predicts late-time accelerated expansion without introducing any free parameters already present in Einstein's theory.

We consider the cosmological evolution in extended Gauss-Bonnet gravity (EGB), which is an extension of general relativity that includes higher-order curvature corrections.
The EGB gravity can be reformulated as a scalar-tensor theory with two additional degrees of freedom, and it belongs to the Horndeski theory family.

We solved a corresponding set of differential equations using numerical methods and found that our model leads to the development of the universe in the late-time acceleration phase without introducing any new free parameters, which is consistent with Einstein's theory.

We consider the problem of quantizing arbitrary vectors on the Grassmann manifold in order to minimize distortion under a given rate constraint, which is related to multi-input multi-output (MIMO) communication systems with feedback.

We deduced the achievable minimum distortion upper bound and the corresponding optimal rate lower bound by using information theory tools, such as the entropy power inequality and the data processing inequality.
Our results indicate that, as the dimension of the underlying Grassmann manifold increases, the performance gap between these two bounds gradually widens.
Finally, we provide numerical examples from our theoretical research.
The work presented here was supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF) under grant number CCF-0635035.

To reduce the required feedback overhead while maintaining good performance, one approach is to utilize Channel State Information (CSI), which refers to the knowledge of the current fading coefficients, to perform joint encoding across multiple transmit antennas.
This technology is called spatial multiplexing or beamforming, and it requires obtaining Channel State Information (CSI) at both the transmitter and receiver ends.

Due to the significant signaling overhead typically involved in obtaining perfect Channel State Information (CSI) at the transmission end through trained schemes, practical implementations often resort to a quantized version of the actual channel state information.

We propose a new method to incorporate the influence of active galactic nuclei (AGN) on their host galaxies and the surrounding interstellar medium into hydrodynamic cosmological simulations based on physical process analysis and description.

The main idea of our method is to utilize the scaling relationships between the observed black hole mass, luminosity, and velocity dispersion, as well as the correlation between radio brightness and the Eddington ratio, to predict the properties of individual active galactic nuclei (AGNs) at each time step of the simulation.
Then, we inject thermal energy or momentum into the surrounding gas particles based on the predicted brightness and speed of these objects.

Our implementation enables us to reproduce multiple observational results, such as the M-σ relation, the fundamental plane of elliptical galaxies, the proportion of red sequence galaxies, and the evolution of galaxy clustering with redshift.

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are one of the largest families of cell surface proteins and play a vital role in many physiological processes, including vision, smell, taste, hormone secretion, nerve conduction, immune response, inflammation, and cancer.

In recent years, due to advances in genomic sequencing technology, the number of known human GPCR sequences has increased dramatically; however, currently only about half of these sequences have been functionally characterized.
In this study, we propose a novel computational method that can predict the functional class of uncharacterized GPCRs based on their sequence similarity to other members within the same subfamily.

Our approach is based on two key ideas: 1) We employ a new adaptive strategy that selects representative sequences by considering the diversity among different subfamilies and their evolutionary relationships; 2) We have developed a new scoring scheme that takes into account not only the similarity between pairwise sequences but also the structural information between the query sequence and the template sequence.
Using our method, we successfully classified over 80% of all human GPCRs, whose functions had previously been experimentally determined.
