We present the results of numerical simulations of planetary systems around binary stars, focusing on the orbital migration effects caused by the tidal interactions between the planets and their host stars.

We found that for most of the initial conditions considered here (except for those with very small semi-major axes), the final orbits tend to become circular due to the tidal forces exerted by the host star on the planet; this is true even when the original orbits are elliptical or inclined relative to the binary plane.

Spontaneous symmetry breaking occurs when a system with multiple symmetries becomes unstable to small perturbations.
This means that even if the original Lagrangian describing the system appears symmetric under certain transformations, the ground state of the system spontaneously breaks these symmetries.
For example, in quantum electrodynamics (QED), photons interact with electrons by exchanging virtual electron-positron pairs.

We present high-resolution numerical simulations of the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations using the LANS-alpha model, which is considered to produce good results for wall-bounded flows at low Reynolds numbers.
We indicate that this method can also be applied to cases with high Reynolds numbers, and although its basic assumptions are no longer valid, it can still yield accurate results.
Compared to the standard large eddy simulation (LES) method, its main advantage is that it does not require the introduction of an explicit subgrid-scale model.
This makes the method very attractive, as it does not require the adjustment of any parameters or coefficients like other large eddy simulation (LES) methods.

Turbulence plays a crucial role in many physical phenomena, including weather forecasting, ocean circulation, and combustion processes.
However, despite decades of research, turbulence remains one of the most challenging problems in computational fluid dynamics.
One reason for this difficulty is the wide range of length scales involved in turbulence.
Due to the fact that large eddies contain most of the kinetic energy, they occupy only a small portion of the total volume.
On the other hand, the smaller eddies nearly fill all the space, but they contribute little to the overall kinetic energy.
Therefore, if one wants to accurately solve all relevant flow structures, an extremely detailed mesh is required, which will lead to very high computational costs.
To address this issue, the so-called Large Eddy Simulation (LES) has been developed in recent years.

These techniques aim to address only the large-scale movements that are responsible for most of the kinetic energy, while using appropriate closure relations to simulate the effects of unresolved small-scale fluctuations.

The primary star is a red giant with a surface temperature of T eff = 5200 K and a surface gravity of log g = 3.9, while its companion star has a mass of M 2 sin i = 0.33 M ⊙.

We propose a method to calculate the effective material properties of thin-layer structures composed of two or more different materials that have periodic microstructures.
The method is based on the combination of homogenization theory and finite element analysis (FEA) to take into account the local interactions between adjacent cells.
We consider three types of cell geometries for simulating various composite materials, such as wire mesh composites, fiber-reinforced polymer matrix composites, and metal foams.
We pay particular attention to composite materials formed by a network of parallel wires arranged periodically and embedded in a uniform medium.
For this type of structure, experiments have shown that the macroscopic elastic modulus largely depends on the volume fraction occupied by the wire.
However, these experimental results cannot be explained by classical homogenization theory, as these theories do not take into account the interaction effects between adjacent conductors.
Therefore, we propose a new theoretical framework here to study the mechanical behavior of network composites at the micro and mesoscopic scales.

We prove that the problem of approaching Nash equilibrium in two-player zero-sum entangled games is NP-hard, even when only focusing on pure strategies and exact equilibria.
We also proved similar results regarding mixed strategy equilibrium.
These results hold without the assumption of standard complexity theory, such as P = NP or RP = NEXP.
The proof uses a reduction from the maximum cut problem for graphs with bounded tree width.

We consider the problem of testing whether an unknown parameter belongs to a given closed interval when the observations are generated by a one-dimensional diffusion process, whose drift and volatility functions depend on this parameter.
We propose a test statistic based on the supremum norm between the empirical distribution function (EDF) based on sample paths and the theoretical corresponding function under the null hypothesis.
The asymptotic behavior of fixed and divergent time ranges has been studied.
In particular, we demonstrate that as the time range increases, our test statistic weakly converges to a functional of the standard Brownian bridge.
This result enables us to derive the exact critical value α of the proposed test through Monte Carlo simulation within any finite time frame.
Finally, the numerical experiments demonstrate the performance comparison of the proposed method with existing tests.
Key terms: detection problem; diffusion process; empirical distribution function; two-tailed alternative hypothesis; critical value; asymptotic normality; finite time detection.

This study focuses on the development and analysis of a mathematical model that describes the kinetics of copolymerization reactions occurring within droplets dispersed in water, which are stabilized by surfactants.
The system consists of three partial differential equations (PDEs) that are coupled at the interface of the two phases through nonlinear boundary conditions.
In addition to the commonly seen convection-diffusion-reaction terms in such models, we also include diffusion resulting from Marangoni stress caused by surface tension gradients at the interface.
We proved the existence of global weak solutions through the Galerkin approximation method combined with compactness arguments.
Finally, we conduct numerical simulations to demonstrate our theoretical results.
Keywords: copolymerization; emulsion; surface tension gradient; mathematical modeling.

1 Introduction  
Polymer materials have been widely used in coatings for solid surfaces or as additives in many industrial processes, including coatings, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and food processing, see for example [21, 22].
A common method for producing these materials is to polymerize monomers into small droplets suspended in water, known as emulsions.
This process can be achieved through chemical or physical means, depending on whether the droplets contain the necessary chemicals to initiate the polymerization reaction.
For example, if the water droplets do not contain any chemicals, they must first be prepared separately before being added to the main mixture that contains all the other ingredients.
Once these are completed, the droplets will begin to increase in size until they are comparable to the wavelength of the light waves passing through them.
At this point, the droplet becomes optically opaque, and growth continues, ultimately leading to the formation of large particles called micelles.
These particles can be separated from the remaining solution using centrifugation or filtration techniques.
Alternatively, another type of emulsifier can be used so that the droplets remain transparent throughout the process.

However, it is important to note that this method requires additional control over the amount of energy supplied during the process, as excessive heat generated by the exothermic characteristics can lead to issues.

The high-energy threshold reaction rates are calculated using the statistical model code TALYS-1.6 for proton-induced reactions with energies up to 800 MeV, and they are compared with experimental data obtained under the "Study of Nuclear Processes under Extreme Conditions" project framework at the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (JINR-Dubna).

The results indicate that the theoretical predictions are in good agreement with the experiments within the range of uncertainty, except in some cases where the measured cross-sections are overestimated or underestimated.

Keywords: reaction rate, thick target, proton beam, statistical model, nuclear physics, cross-section measurement, high-energy threshold reaction rate calculation, extreme conditions study, projectile fragmentation, heavy ion collisions, energy deposition, radiation damage, lead target, inverse dynamics, fragmentation function, neutron emission probability distribution, excitation function, stopping power, energy loss fluctuations, energy transfer.
We studied the efficiency of a token system in which users can purchase goods using their own currency or by exchanging it for the currency (tokens) of others.
We indicate that when there are many buyers and sellers using such a system for trading goods, if the majority have the motivation to become fair traders, then the system is efficient.
However, we also found that this does not always happen, as some users may attempt to hoard money, while others may engage in altruistic behavior.
Specifically, we consider two types of user behavior: selfish and altruistic.
Selfish users maximize their utility in each transaction; they will only accept offers that provide them with more than the amount they pay.
The altruistic users do not care about maximizing their own benefits, but rather hope to ensure that everyone can receive as much reward as possible.
We use game theory models to analyze these behaviors and derive the conditions for fair behavior of selfish users and altruistic users.

In this work, we consider the problem of optimizing the performance of multi-hop wireless mesh networks (WMN), where each node is equipped with multiple antennas and communicates with its neighbors using vector broadcast channels.
We proposed an algorithm that jointly optimizes the routing tree in the network layer and the beamforming vectors in the physical layer to support unicast and multicast traffic.
The proposed algorithm can be implemented solely through the exchange of local information between neighboring nodes.
Our simulation results show that under different channel conditions, our algorithm outperforms existing algorithms in end-to-end throughput, with improvements of up to 50%.
Keywords - Wireless Mesh Network, Cross-Layer Optimization, Beamforming, Routing Tree, Multicast.
1 Introduction: Wireless mesh networks are becoming increasingly popular due to their low cost and ease of deployment [1].
In such a network, the transmission range of all nodes is limited, so it is necessary to relay packets through other nodes in order to reach the destination.
This introduces additional overhead for network resources, including bandwidth consumption and energy loss [2].
To improve the efficiency of Wireless Mesh Networks (WMNs), recent research indicates that joint design of the network layer and physical layer is necessary.
The network layer determines how to route packets, while the physical layer decides what transmission power level should be used and what beamforming vector should be applied.
However, most previous studies have either focused on the network layer or the physical layer.

We present an analysis of the high-resolution Hα and Ca II K line observations obtained by the Solar Optical Telescope (SOT) on May 24, 2007, when a large sunspot group was observed at the center of the solar disk.
The main feature is a bright dot-like structure (light bridge) located between the two holes.
We found that the temperature of this light bridge is about 1000K higher than the surrounding area.
This result suggests that magnetic reconnection may be occurring there.
In addition to the light bridges, we also observed small-scale structures, such as spicules and fibers, which may be related to the magnetic field configuration around the light bridges.
These features can provide important information for understanding the formation mechanism of light bridges.

We analyzed the optical and infrared photometric data of the dwarf nova system V2051 Oph, which has been observed recently (2006-2008). This system is one of the three known systems that have undergone both superoutbursts and normal outbursts simultaneously during their lifetimes.
We found that the light curve of this object has many similarities with the light curves observed in other SU UMa type systems, but there are also some significant differences.

It is particularly noteworthy that after the first and second hypernova outbreaks, we did not observe any clear signs of brightness re-enhancement; nor did we find evidence of a double-peaked structure in the light curves of these events at any stage.
The lack of these features may be due to our observations being made during a period when the system was relatively dim compared to previous studies.
However, it should be noted that the orbital period of V2051 Oph is significantly longer than that of most other SU UMa-type stars, so the mass transfer rate will be reduced by about ten times.

We present for the first time a fully self-consistent atomic-level quantum transport calculation of ballistic graphene nanoribbons (GNRs) with realistic band structure and electrostatic potential distributions, using a method that combines nonequilibrium Green’s function formalism with density functional theory (DFT).
We show that the electronic properties of graphene nanoribbons greatly depend on their width and edge structure.

The calculated current-voltage characteristics exhibit several interesting features, such as the negative differential resistance generated at low bias due to the resonant tunneling effect of localized states near the Fermi level.

In addition, we found that the presence of the hydrogen passivation layer can significantly improve device performance, as it suppresses the backscattering effect caused by defects or impurities along the edges.
Keywords: ballistic transport, graphene nanoribbons, nonequilibrium Green's function, density functional theory, quantum transport calculations.

We present the results of an unbiased survey of compact HII regions in the southern galactic plane using data obtained from the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA).

The sample includes all known OB stars located at |b| < 1 degree and within a distance of less than 5,000 parsecs, which are associated with IRAS point sources classified as having infrared excess, indicating the presence of circumstellar disks or envelopes.
We have detected over 100 new compact HII regions, with frequencies ranging from 2.1 GHz to 6.0 GHz.
The sizes of these objects range from 0.01 pc to 0.5 pc, and their brightness varies by more than four orders of magnitude.

Most of these newly discovered compact HII regions appear to be excited by a single O-type star; however, we also found a few cases where two or three bright radio components are separated by only a few tenths of an arcsecond.
Through addition, we have identified some previously uncatalogued ultra-compact HII regions that are smaller than 0.01 parsecs.
We analyzed the X-ray properties of 12 hyper-luminous infrared galaxies (HLIRGs) using observations from XMM-Newton, with data sourced from AO-1 and AO-2.
The selection criterion for HLIRG samples is L(8-1000μm) > 10^12L_sun, where L(8-1000μm) is obtained by integrating the best-fit spectral energy distribution (SED) for each source.
We found that all sources have significance exceeding 5 standard deviations in the 0.3-10 keV band; however, only two objects showed clear evidence of absorption above the Galactic level.
For these two absorption systems, we derive the column densities NH = 1.7 x 10^23 cm^{-2} and 2.1 x 10^22 cm^{-2}, respectively.

The hardness ratio is calculated using the formula HR = (H - S) / (H + S), where H and S represent the counts in the 3-7 keV and 0.3-2 keV bands, respectively. We found that there is no correlation between HR and brightness or redshift.
This indicates that the intrinsic spectral shape of this population may have evolved little, if at all, in the range of z = 2.6.
The chemical composition of type II variable stars is studied using high-resolution spectra obtained from Subaru/HDS, Keck/HIRES, VLT/UVES, and McDonald/DEIMOS spectrographs.
We found that our sample stars all have solar or super-solar metallicity ([Fe/H] > +0.2).
In addition to the iron I line, we also use the magnesium I triplet lines to more accurately determine their atmospheric parameters.
For some of these stars, we detect significant overabundance of CNO elements and s-process elements; however, there is no obvious correlation between the abundance patterns and the pulsation periods.
The results indicate that the observed abundance anomalies may be due to mass transfer during the binary star evolution process, rather than internal mixing processes related to stellar pulsation.
This work was supported by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) priority area scientific research grant (No. 16071203).

We study the problem of finding an optimal set of points on the unit circle that are equidistant from each other and have the minimum angular separation, known as Costas arrays or Costas configurations.
We demonstrate how to formulate this problem as a convex optimization problem with linear constraints, defined in a probability measure space supported on the unit circle.
This formula allows us to efficiently solve it using the tools of convex analysis.
We provide a polynomial-time algorithm that computes an approximate solution within any desired precision range.
The proposed method is based on the Frank-Wolfe (FW) algorithm and incorporates the Sinkhorn-Knopp scaling technique.
Finally, numerical experiments have demonstrated the effectiveness of our method compared to existing methods.
Keywords: convex optimization; probability measure; Frank-Wolfe algorithm; scaling technique; unit circle; Costas array; Costas configuration.
We present the discovery and analysis of two double neutron stars (DNSs) with masses exceeding 2 times the solar mass, namely PSR J0737-3039A/B and PSR B1913+16.
The former is a binary star system, observed to have an orbital decay rate consistent with the emission of gravitational waves; it will merge in about 3 million years.
The latter refers to a pulsar orbiting around its companion star's helium core, which has expelled most of its hydrogen-rich outer layers during mass transfer while on the red giant branch.

We believe that these systems provide evidence for two different formation mechanisms of binary neutron stars: one involves the formation of two components during normal stellar evolution, while the other occurs when one component forms through this process, while the other is born as a black hole or a massive white dwarf.
This second mechanism may be the reason for some short gamma-ray bursts.

We have proposed an open-source framework called Bubblesched, which allows for the construction of portable thread schedulers for heterogeneous multi-processors (HMP).
The main idea is to use bubbles as scheduling units and to schedule them using a set of rules at different levels of the HMP hierarchy.
We have implemented two schedulers: one based on task stealing and the other based on load balancing.
Both schedulers can run efficiently on top of Bubblesched without any modifications.

Our experimental results show that the performance of the two schedulers in parallel applications running fine-grained tasks is improved by up to 3 times compared to the current state-of-the-art solutions.

We propose an open-source framework called Bubblesched, which allows for the construction of portable thread schedulers for heterogeneous multi-processors (HMP) that can run efficiently on them without any modifications.
The framework treats bubbles as scheduling units and uses a set of rules to schedule across various levels of the HMP hierarchy.
We have implemented two types of schedulers: one based on preemptive work, and the other supported by load balancing.
The two schedulers successfully executed on Bubblesched without any modifications.

Our experimental results indicate that the performance of these two schedulers is up to 3 times higher than that of state-of-the-art solutions when running parallel applications with fine-grained tasks.

Additionally, we illustrate that the framework can be used to make efficient task-parallel algorithms such as task-coloring and regular matrix multiplication.

We proposed an algorithm that learns model parameters by optimizing the log-likelihood of a probabilistic model using Monte Carlo (MC) sampling, which we call Monte Carlo Sampling-based Parameter Learning, abbreviated as PLMS.
We prove that as the number of samples approaches infinity, this method is equivalent to maximum likelihood estimation.
However, in practice, it is more efficient than standard gradient-based optimization methods, as it does not require calculating the gradients of all data points in each iteration.
On the contrary, each iteration only needs to generate one sample in order to calculate the objective function value and update the parameter values accordingly.
This makes our approach particularly suitable for large datasets, where evaluating the objective function may take too much time.
Our experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets indicate that PLMS outperforms state-of-the-art algorithms, such as stochastic gradient descent and Adam, in terms of accuracy and efficiency.

The brain is an organ that has evolved to be dynamic and plastic, capable of continually changing its structure in response to internal and external stimuli.
The human brain can change throughout life by forming new connections between neurons or eliminating existing ones.
This ability enables humans to adapt to their environment and continuously learn.

However, this flexibility also makes it susceptible to damage caused by diseases, injuries, aging, and other factors, which may lead to neurological disorders such as Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease, epilepsy, traumatic brain injury, and multiple sclerosis.
In recent years, significant progress has been made in neuroscience research, aiming to understand how the brain works and to develop treatments for these diseases.
One method is to use neural prosthetic devices that replace damaged parts of the brain with artificial components, which can perform similar functions.
Neuroprosthetics is an electronic system designed to interface directly with the nervous system to restore functions lost due to injury or disease.

These devices include microelectrodes implanted in brain tissue to record electrical activity; stimulating electrodes placed near or on nerves to deliver electrical stimulation; and wireless communication connections for transmitting the data collected by the recording electrodes and/or control signals generated by the stimulating electrodes back to a computer located outside the body.

We introduce the concept of cover homology, which is an extension of ordinary homology to infinite graphs and simplicial complexes.
The main idea of this concept is that we consider not only finite subcomposites but also their infinite counterparts—what are known as covers.

We introduced the first version of our new code WHAM (Weno-Hybrid Arbitrary Mesh), which is based on the recently developed Weighted Essentially Non-Oscillatory (WENO) scheme for solving one-dimensional and multi-dimensional hyperbolic conservation laws.

We propose the DNA Hash Pool (DHP) as an efficient data structure for compressively storing large amounts of biological sequences, suitable for applications such as sequence alignment, database searching, and genome assembly.
The basic concept of DHP is that similar sequences have common substrings that can be represented by short binary codes called hashes.
The main idea of our method is to store all possible hash values, rather than storing each sequence individually.

The first law of thermodynamics is often seen as a statement about entropy, but it can be derived in other ways.
This article presents a derivation using statistical mechanics and information theory.
The result is that entropy is defined as a measure of uncertainty related to the state (or lack of state) of a system.
The entropy increases when the possible states increase, and these states are those where we cannot predict what will happen in the system.
In this sense, entropy measures how much our knowledge decreases when we learn new information about the surrounding world.
The second law of thermodynamics states that entropy always increases over time.
However, if you carefully examine the above definition of entropy, you will find that it is not clear whether entropy actually increases over time.
To answer this question, we consider two different systems, A and B, both of which are initially in a state of equilibrium.
System A has only one possible configuration, while System B has many possible configurations.
If we could observe these systems, we would find that they have exactly the same energy levels and temperature.
But now imagine that we are observing them through a small window, so we cannot know what is happening inside each system.
We can conclude that the temperature of system A seems to be higher than that of system B, as we have less uncertainty about its future behavior.
Now let's assume we let system A evolve into system C, in which all particles are arranged in a completely ordered manner.
The translation is: "Then system C seems cooler than system A, even though their energy remains unchanged."
So far, we have observed that entropy does not necessarily increase over time.

We study a type of evolutionary stable strategy (ESS) and its stability characteristics in a two-sided incomplete information ultimatum game, where one player knows the type of the opponent, while the other player does not have such information.
We prove that when the type set is finite or compactly supported on [0, 1], there exists a unique evolutionary stable strategy (ESS) that is consistent with the Nash equilibrium.
If this set contains unbounded elements, then we prove that the ESS (Evolutionary Stable Strategy) may be unstable under small perturbations of the payoff function.
Specifically, it can be shown that any evolutionary stable strategy (ESS) must satisfy certain conditions related to the distribution function of types.
Finally, we provide some numerical examples to illustrate our results.
The study of evolutionary game theory investigates how strategies evolve over time when players interact repeatedly in large populations.
It provides a natural framework for analyzing the strategic interactions among self-interested agents who cannot make commitments in advance but have the opportunity to learn by observing past games.
A typical example of this situation occurs in bargaining problems, where each participant makes offers in turn, without knowing what the opponent will propose.
This issue was first studied by Guth et al. (1982), who introduced the so-called ultimatum game as a bargaining model between two selfish individuals.
For this game, Player 1 proposes to allocate a fixed amount M as shares x and y = M - x, respectively offered to themselves and Player 2; Player 2 can either accept or reject this proposal.
If he accepts, the two players will receive their respective shares according to the proposal; otherwise, they will gain nothing.

Since the pioneering research by Guth and others, many authors have investigated various aspects of the ultimatum game, including the existence and multiplicity of equilibria, and the efficiency losses resulting from a lack of commitment ability.
(See, for example, Binmore & Shaked, 1993; Ochs & Roth, 1989).
However, all this work assumes that there is complete information available to the participants.

We provide deep radio observations at 1.4 GHz obtained from VLA, targeting two TeV gamma-ray emission regions: one associated with the open cluster Cyg OB2 #8 (HESS J1640-465) and the other located near the giant star WR 25 (HESS J1641-463).
The new data reveals a wide range of emission phenomena around the two TeV sources, which were not observed in previous surveys.
We discussed the possible emission scenarios based on our results as well as the recent results obtained by other authors.
We specifically point out that the observed structure is due to the synchrotron radiation produced by relativistic electrons accelerated in shock waves driven by stellar winds.

Finally, we used the standard model of particle acceleration in colliding wind binary stars to estimate the required magnetic field strength for generating this radiation.

Introduction: The Cygnus OB2 star cluster contains more than 100 OB stars, distributed over an area of approximately 50 square degrees, with central coordinates at longitude l = 80° and latitude b = 1° (see Figure 1a).
There are suggestions that many of them may be members of binary systems or even multiple star systems (e.g., Knödlseder 2000; Wright et al. 2010).
These objects can drive powerful winds into the surrounding environment, generating intense impacts that accelerate particles to very high energies.

If some of these particles escape from the shock front, they will interact with photons from the surrounding interstellar medium, producing high-energy electromagnetic radiation, which can be detected over a broad range of the electromagnetic spectrum, including the TeV range.
Multiple studies indicate that several known TeV sources in the sky may be related to young open star clusters like Cygnus OB2 (see, for example, Aharonian et al., 2005a, b, 2007a).

However, only a few of these associations have been confirmed through multi-wavelength observational activities, including optical/infrared imaging, spectroscopy, and/or radio continuum observations (see, for example, Reimer & Böttcher 2006, Castro-Tirado et al.).

The luminosity of this source is 2 x 10^39 erg/s, assuming it is located at a distance of 8 kpc.
The position of the second source is RA=12h54m55s.7 and Dec=69°59'46'', with a count rate of 0.9 x 10^-3 counts sec^-1.
If it is located at a distance of 8,000 parsecs, its luminosity is approximately 2 x 10^39 erg/second.
These two sources seem to be variable, with time scales fluctuating between hours and days.
These results suggest that the two sources may contain black holes close to their Eddington limits.

We present the substructure analysis results from 62 galaxy clusters, which were observed using the XMM-Newton and Chandra telescopes and selected from the all-sky survey of the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE).
We use two different methods to identify substructures in each galaxy cluster: the Dressler & Shectman test and the Voronoi tessellation technique.
The main objective is to study the performance of these techniques when applied solely to X-ray data or in conjunction with photometry in the infrared.
Our research results indicate that in most cases, both tests are able to detect significant substructures; however, some differences between them are also highlighted.
For example, we found that compared to the VTT method, the Dressler and Shechter methods tend to overestimate the number of substructures.
In addition, by combining optical/infrared information with X-ray data, detection efficiency can be improved by up to 30%.
Finally, we will compare our results with those obtained from other galaxy cluster samples detected through the Sunyaev-Zel'dovich effect.
We introduce the concept of neural networks, which are graphs that represent the relationships between sequences and shapes in an unsupervised manner.
We demonstrated how to use these methods for shape recognition, specifically by training with synthetic data generated through computer graphics techniques.
The generated network can accurately recognize shapes, even when they have been transformed or distorted.
Finally, we demonstrate our approach on images from the real world, showing its good generalization capability beyond the training set.
In this work, we propose a new method to learn shapes through the relationship between shapes and sequences.
Our main contribution is the introduction of the concept of neutral networks to learn these relationships in an unsupervised manner.
A neural network is a graph in which the nodes correspond to sequences (such as strings), and the edges connect similar sequences.
They provide a natural representation for capturing the relationships between different types of information.
For example, neural networks can be used to capture the relationships between sentences and documents, or between musical notes and melodies.
Here, we focus on applying neural networks to the problem of shape recognition based solely on point sequences sampled along the boundary.
This task has many applications, including medical image analysis, where it may not always be possible to obtain true labels due to privacy issues.
We propose an efficient data redistribution scheme that allows for parallel computation on dynamically resizable computation domains in a distributed memory environment.
The proposed method is based on a multi-dimensional block cyclic distribution and maps the blocks to processors using a filled space curve, thereby exploiting locality.
We demonstrated how to effectively redistribute data between different processor configurations using this technology, while minimizing communication overhead.
Our experimental results show that there is a significant improvement in performance when executing applications with dynamic load balancing requirements compared to existing methods.
In particular, we have achieved acceleration of up to 3 times compared to the state-of-the-art techniques proposed in literature [1].

Quantum repeaters have been proposed to overcome losses in quantum communication channels, using entangled photons and linear optical components such as beam splitters, phase shifters, and single-photon detectors.
From this work, we demonstrate an experimental demonstration of a quantum repeater, which consists of two remote nodes connected by a 50-kilometer optical fiber link.

The system consists of three parts: (1) generation, (2) transmission, and (3) detection of photon pairs from each node; (4) Bell state measurement between two nodes; and (5) feedforward operation on the received qubits based on the results of the Bell state measurement.
We have successfully demonstrated all of these parts, except for the feedforward operation that is currently under development.
Our results show that our current setup can generate high-quality entanglement over distances of up to 50 kilometers.
This experiment paves the way for the practical application of quantum networks.
Quantum repeaters have been proposed to address the issues caused by channel loss in quantum communication systems.

The multifractal properties of human heartbeats have been studied by many authors, but most research has focused on short time series (usually less than one hour).

In this study, we investigated the scaling properties of long-term electrocardiogram (ECG) recordings during sleep in healthy individuals, using wavelet transform to calculate the singular spectrum f(α) to characterize the multifractal nature present in each signal.
We found that all signals exhibit a broad exponent α, indicating strong multifractality.
The width of these spectra Δα decreases with the increase of recording time T, showing a relationship of Δα ~ T^(-1/2), applicable for T reaching 10 hours.
This indicates that when considering longer recordings, the electrocardiogram becomes more monofractal in characteristics.
Finally, we demonstrate how our research findings can be used to detect pathological changes in heart rate variability associated with congestive heart failure.

Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are promising materials for field emitter devices due to their unique physical and chemical properties, such as high aspect ratio, low work function, and excellent mechanical strength.
In this study, we propose an integrated multiphysics model that can be used to simulate the system response of carbon nanotube (CNT)-based field emission diodes (FEDs).
The proposed model consists of three sub-models: 1) electron transport in carbon nanotubes; 2) electrostatic potential distribution; 3) current density distribution.
We developed these models using the COMSOL Multiphysics software package with built-in physics modules.

To verify our simulation results, we grew vertically aligned carbon nanotubes on a silicon substrate using plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition and then sputtered a layer of gold onto them, thus fabricating a CNT-FED device.
Our experimental data aligns well with the simulation results obtained from the proposed model.

We study the phase transitions induced by noise in systems with multiplicative white noise, Gaussian noise, Poisson noise, or Lévy noise.
We prove that for these three types of noise, there exists an optimal noise intensity at which the system undergoes a transition to a state that performs better than it does in the absence of noise.
The optimal noise intensity varies depending on whether we consider additive noise or multiplicative noise.
For multiplicative noise, they also depend on the shape of the noise power spectral density (PSD).
Especially, if there is a peak in the power spectral density near zero frequency, then as the width of this peak increases, the optimal noise intensity will decrease.
If the power spectral density (PSD) does not have such peaks but monotonically decreases to zero frequency, then the optimal noise intensity will increase as the rate of decay slows down.
Finally, if the decay rate of the power spectral density (PSD) is faster than exponential decay, the optimal noise intensity remains constant and is independent of the decay rate of the PSD.

We reported the growth of millimeter-thick vertically aligned single-walled carbon nanotube forests on SiO2/Si substrates through chemical vapor deposition, using iron nanoparticles as catalysts, in an Ar/H2 atmosphere at temperatures ranging from 700°C to 850°C.
The diameter distribution is centered around 1 nanometer, with an average tube length of approximately 10 micrometers.
We found that the density of the growing forest linearly increases over time until it reaches a maximum value of 3 × 10^11 cm⁻², which corresponds to a volume fraction of 0.7 for the tubes.
This high density can be explained by considering the balance between the nucleation rate and the growth rate of individual pipes.
In addition, we demonstrated that the vertical arrangement of the pipes maintains good quality over a larger area (1 cm²) without any obvious defects or cracks.
These results indicate that these dense forests are promising candidates for applications such as field emitters and transparent electrodes.

We study the dynamics of one-dimensional open quantum systems, focusing on their ability to generate entanglement between spatially distant locations and how this ability is affected by decoherence.

We consider two different system-environment interaction models: (i) an environment that is locally coupled with each location; (ii) an environment that is globally coupled with all locations simultaneously.

In these two cases, we find that there are certain mechanisms that allow the system to be driven into a highly entangled state even if it starts in a state of no entanglement or only weak entanglement.
This occurs because the environment, as a source of noise, drives the system to evolve towards its ground state.
The effect of local coupling is more pronounced than that of global coupling because local coupling allows for faster relaxation time scales.

We present the results of the ground state energy and wave function of positronium obtained by solving the relativistic Schrödinger equation with Coulomb potential using the variational method.
The calculation is performed under two different approximations, namely the non-relativistic limit (NR) and first-order perturbation theory (PT1).
For the NR approximation, we use a Hylleraas-type trial wave function that includes spin-related terms up to the second power of the inter-particle distance.
We also use this wave function to calculate the expectation value of the kinetic energy operator.

In the PT1 approximation, we use Hylleraas-type variational wave functions, including spin-dependent terms, taking into account the third power of the inter-particle distance, as well as a Dirac orbital for a single electron as the basis set.
The binding energy value we calculated is in good agreement with the previously reported results.

We present the results of photometric and spectral studies of blue bar (BP) stars in four nearby dwarf elliptical galaxies: Draco, Ursa Major II, Sculptor, and Fornax.

Another possibility is that the bluer component represents a younger generation of stars that formed in a recent star formation event.

We study the properties of a Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC) formed by an arbitrary number N of particles trapped in a harmonic oscillator potential, and these particles are exposed to a disordered external potential.
We indicate that, for any intensity of disorder, there is always a finite proportion of atoms localized at each position in the lattice.
As the disorder increases, the localization length decreases, but even when the level of disorder is much larger than the interatomic interaction energy, it still retains macroscopic characteristics.
This result holds true in both one-dimensional and high-dimensional cases.
Specifically, we found that the critical disorder beyond all states localization scales as 1/N in one dimension and as 1/d in two and three dimensions, where d is the spatial dimension.
Our results provide a microscopic understanding for recent experiments on ultracold atomic gases in optical lattices.

We present the results of metal and molecular gas cooling in cosmological hydrodynamic simulations using Enzo, with a focus on the impact of different numerical schemes (smoothed particle hydrodynamics versus grid-based computations) on the solution of the energy equations, as well as the effects of various physical prescriptions on star formation feedback.
We found that, compared to grid-based methods, SPH codes tend to overestimate the amount of cold gas at high redshifts, primarily due to artificial viscous heating.
The feedback model that includes galactic winds can mitigate this effect by removing low-entropy material from galaxies.
However, we also show that if these wind models remove too much of the hot halo gas surrounding the massive halos, they may lead to an underestimation of the total mass fraction of cold gas.

Introduction

In recent years, there has been growing interest in understanding how gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) produce their broad-band electromagnetic radiation.

This effort has led to several successful models for describing the early phases of gamma-ray burst (GRB) emissions (see, for example, Piran 2005; Zhang 2007), but there has been less progress in explaining the origin of the afterglow component.
A key feature of most afterglows is the apparent steepening or "jet break" that occurs in the light curves about one day after the burst (Rhoads 1999).

Such interruptions are typically interpreted as indicating that the relativistic outflows become optically thin, leading to a decrease in self-absorption of synchrotron radiation, which in turn causes the flux density to drop rapidly.

However, some authors believe that this interruption may also be due to the projectiles from the explosion occurring under continuous energy input (e.g., Kumar and Panaitescu 2000; Granot et al. 2001; Chevalier and Li 2000), while others suggest that it may be due to changes in the geometry of the emission region (e.g., Racusin et al. 2008).

In isolated systems, equilibrium fluctuations are studied using statistical mechanics and information theory.

We introduced the discovery of SN 2005hj (PTF10ygu), along with its photometric measurements and spectral observations. SN 2005hj is an apparently normal, bright Type Ia supernova discovered by PTF at the end of March 2005, with a redshift of z = 0.084.

Cataclysmic variable stars (CVs), also known as dwarf novae, are a type of close binary star system composed of a white dwarf primary and a late-type secondary star that fills its Roche lobe.
Matter is transferred to the surface of the white dwarf through the internal Lagrange point L1, where it forms an accretion disk around the compact object.

This process leads to periodic outbursts triggered by thermal instabilities in the accretion disk, resulting in brightness variations that can change dramatically over timescales ranging from hours to years.

If this is true, it would mean that some of these stars exploded into space while still surrounded by dense stellar winds or envelopes.
These environments will significantly influence the dynamics of the explosion and the characteristics of the released radiation.

For example, Chevalier et al. (2004) demonstrated that if the density distribution of the surrounding medium follows a power law of r^-2, the resulting light curve will exhibit a plateau phase, followed by a rapid decay phase.

We introduce the concept of algebraic charge liquid, which is defined as the ground state of a Hamiltonian with local interactions that can be represented by fermionic creation and annihilation operators.
We demonstrate how to construct such a model by providing an explicit representation of a finite group G in the Hilbert space of spinless fermions.
The generated model can be exactly solved when G has no non-trivial subgroups.
In this case, we find that there is at least one phase transition, which occurs between different phases characterized by different topological orders.
For example, if \( G = \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \), then our construction will produce two gapped phases distinguished by their chiral central charge \( c^- = 0 \) or \( 1 \).

If the group G contains a nontrivial subgroup H, then the system will exhibit excitations without energy gaps, which correspondingly correspond to particles transformed according to the irreducible representations (irreps) of H.
These results provide new insights into the classification problem of quantum many-body systems.
We study the dynamics of the supercritical bifurcation points in a non-integrable Hamiltonian system with two degrees of freedom, using perturbation theory and numerical simulations.
We indicate that an infinite number of periodic orbits, as well as an infinite family of quasi-periodic solutions, arise at the bifurcation point.
The latter is solved numerically by calculating the Lyapunov exponents along the trajectory starting from a position close to the equilibrium (corresponding to the undisturbed problem).
The results presented here can be applied to several physical systems, such as Josephson junctions or pendulums coupled through elastic elements.
Supercritical bifurcation occurs when a stable fixed point loses stability under small disturbances.
In this situation, new types of attractors will emerge nearby, including limit cycles and chaotic sets.
This phenomenon has been extensively studied both theoretically and experimentally (see, for example, [1], [3]).
However, most studies are limited to low-dimensional dynamic systems, where explicit expressions for all relevant quantities can be obtained.
Here, we consider high-dimensional problems for which only approximate methods exist.
Our main motivation comes from nonlinear physics, but our results may also be applicable to other fields, such as biology or economics.
We study the dynamics of free fermions jumping between various nodes in an arbitrary connected graph, not limited to nearest-neighbor hopping.
We indicate that the system is equivalent to a set of independent random walkers that evolve in parallel and interact through pair collisions at the vertices.
The collision rate depends solely on the number of particles at each vertex; it is zero in graphs without cycles or multiple edges (such as trees), but it can be arbitrarily large in other cases.
The model exhibits interesting behavior even when all rates are equal, characterized by anomalous diffusion and superdiffusion.
Specifically, we prove that for any tree graph, the mean square displacement grows according to t^(3/2) with time, while for general graphs, its growth rate is faster than t^(2/3).
Finally, we discussed possible extensions of our results beyond the case of free fermions.

The idea that the universe experienced a phase of rapid expansion in its very early stages is now widely accepted by cosmologists as one possible explanation for many observed features of our current universe, such as its flatness and uniformity.
In this speech, I will discuss how to use the ideas from string theory to construct inflationary models that are consistent with current observations.
The basic idea of these structures is that they involve membranes that move in extra dimensions of space-time.
These membranes will move closer to or farther away from each other depending on their initial conditions.
If two membranes collide, it will lead to a rapid expansion of spacetime, which is referred to as "inflation."

We believe that the observed metallicity enhancement in certain post-T Tauri stars (PTTS) may be due to their accretion of planetary material during the formation phase, followed by the rapid formation of planets and their ejection into space.

We indicate that this scenario can explain the high metallic abundance found in PTTS, as well as the low abundance ratio of refractory elements such as magnesium/silicon or aluminum/silicon compared to what is expected when these celestial bodies are formed through the standard core-accretion process.
The proposed mechanism also explains why there are no known close-in giant planets in PTTS, even though they have already passed their protoplanetary disk phase.
The model predicts that most PTTS should have at least one planet with a mass equivalent to that of Jupiter, orbiting on a wide orbit beyond 1 AU.
In addition, we predict that many PTTS will exhibit an infrared excess due to the dust debris disk generated by collisions between planetary bodies.
We analyzed the distribution of orbital parameters and mass for all known exoplanets with measured mass in the solar system (N=73).
We found that this sample can be divided into three different groups, namely super-Earths, small Neptune-like planets, and hot Jupiters.
The first two are characterized by their low eccentricity and high orbital mutual inclination; in contrast, hot Jupiters have smaller mutual inclinations but larger eccentricities.
Super-Earths and mini-Neptunes seem to also form different sequences in the radius-mass diagram.
These results suggest that these three populations may represent different formation mechanisms or evolutionary histories.

In particular, our research findings support previous suggestions that super-Earths are formed through core accretion, followed by significant inward migration, while mini-Neptunes may be assembled through gravitational instability.
Finally, we demonstrated how these results can be used as prior knowledge for searching for other exoplanets through transit surveys (such as Kepler).

We study the patterns of global economic activity by analyzing the World Trade Network (WTW). The World Trade Network is an interconnected network that represents international transactions between countries.
We found that WTW exhibits properties of scale-free networks, small-world characteristics, and community structure.
The characteristics of these communities are a high density of internal links, but a low density of links to other communities.
In addition to these structural characteristics, we also study the flow of goods in different parts of the network over time.
Our results show that there are several different stages at certain locations in the network where the flow of goods significantly increases or decreases.
These findings indicate that the current state of the economy can be inferred from the topological characteristics of WTW.
This work provides new insights into the dynamics of the global economy, helping us better understand its evolution.

We conducted new observations of the W3 giant molecular cloud in the millimeter wavebands (1.2 mm and 3 mm). The W3 giant molecular cloud is one of the most active star formation regions in our galaxy.
We have detected hundreds of compact sources, with masses ranging from 0.01 to 10 times the mass of the Sun.
Most of these objects are related to infrared dark clouds, which contain young stellar objects surrounded by dense cocoon layers.
These results indicate that massive stars are formed from gravity-bound cores in interstellar molecular clouds.
This process may be regulated by turbulence and/or magnetic fields.

Keywords: Star Formation, Infrared Dark Clouds, Millimeter Astronomy, Giant Molecular Clouds

1 Introduction

Massive stars play a significant role in shaping their environment through feedback processes such as radiation pressure, winds, and supernova explosions.
However, it is still unclear how they were formed.
One possibility is that, like low-mass stars, massive stars also form through gravity collapse of dense cores within giant molecular clouds (GMCs) (e.g., McKee & Ostriker 2007).
Alternatively, superstars may form directly from turbulence, without any intermediate core stage (e.g., Banerjee et al. 2006).
To investigate this issue, we observed the W3 region using the Submillimeter Array (SMA; Ho et al., 2004) on two nights in November 2005, located at the Mauna Kea Observatory.
The SMA consists of eight 6-meter antennas and is capable of operating simultaneously at three different frequencies, which are focused on 230 GHz, 345 GHz, and 690 GHz.
At each frequency, there are four basebands covering a continuous transmission bandwidth of 2 GHz and a spectral line research bandwidth of 4 GHz.
The size range of the main beam is from about 5 arcseconds to about 20 arcseconds, depending on the observation frequency.
The total integration time is approximately 12 hours, distributed over six tracks, primarily conducted at night.
The detailed information on the observation setup can be found in Wu et al. (2007a), where we present preliminary results based solely on data obtained at 345 GHz.
Here, we report the results obtained in all three frequency bands.

Extracting freshwater and energy from the atmosphere has been proposed as an alternative to traditional sources, as the supply of traditional sources is limited or harmful to the environment.

This process involves using solar energy to concentrate moisture from the atmosphere into liquid water, and then collecting this water on surfaces coated with hydrophobic materials, allowing it to be easily transported through air flow.
This technology can provide clean drinking water to remote communities without the need for large land areas or significant infrastructure investment.
It also has potential applications in agriculture, where it can provide irrigation at a low cost using wind-powered sprayers.
In addition, the collected water can be used directly as fuel when combined with an electrolyzer powered by renewable electricity.
The process requires minimal maintenance after installation and will operate for many years.
During the period from 2011 to 2013, a pilot-scale demonstration system was constructed near Tucson, Arizona, USA.
The results indicate that under favorable conditions, the system can produce up to 1 gallon of drinkable water per day.

We proposed the first exact solution that describes the case of a rapidly rotating neutron star surrounded by an axisymmetric, stationary, and force-free magnetic field structure, with an arbitrary inclination angle between the star's rotation axis and magnetic axis.
The model is based on the assumption that the surface of the star is covered with a thin layer of plasma, which rotates together with the star at all latitudes.
We demonstrate how to use this solution to calculate the X-ray light curves produced by hotspots located at different latitudes on the surface of a star.

In particular, we demonstrate that if we assume the two emitting components originate from two antipodal heat spots located near the magnetic poles, the observed phase shift and relative amplitude between the soft X-ray peaks (0.5-2 keV) and hard X-ray peaks (2-10 keV) can be reproduced very accurately.

This result suggests that the observed X-ray pulses may be due to the rotational modulation of the local luminosity rather than the Doppler effect caused by the overall motion of matter within the luminous region.

The discovery of over 100 new dwarf galaxies orbiting the Milky Way has sparked a renewed interest in understanding the formation history of our galaxy cluster.

Although many newly discovered systems seem to follow scaling relations similar to those of brighter dwarf galaxies (such as classical dwarf elliptical galaxies), there are still some puzzling differences between them.
For example, although most bright dwarf stars exhibit significant rotation speeds, only one of the recently discovered faint satellites shows any evidence of rotation.
In addition, although most of the bright dwarf stars are located near the virtual radius of the Milky Way, nearly half of the darker satellites are located at distances exceeding 300 kiloparsecs.
In addition to these observational challenges, theoretical models predict that the number of subhalos that dark matter halos should contain is far fewer than the number currently known to exist.

Abstract: We report new stellar asteroseismic analysis results for the main-sequence F-type star Alpha Centauri A, which is part of a close binary system with its cooler companion star B.

Our research is based on high-precision radial velocity measurements obtained with the HARPS instrument installed at the La Silla Observatory in the Andes Mountains of Chile (ESO's 3.6-meter telescope). These measurements were collected over more than four years and are combined with photometric observations conducted in synchrony with the CoRoT space mission.

By applying standard techniques used in stellar asteroseismology, we have detected several periodic signals in two datasets, including one signal whose periodicity exactly matches the orbital period of the system.
This discovery confirms the previous suggestion that the pulsation behavior of this star may be influenced by tidal effects caused by a companion star.
Through the addition, our analysis revealed another set of signals, with corresponding periods ranging from about 1 day to almost 2 days.
These signals can be interpreted as oscillations of rotationally split p modes excited in the convective envelope of the star.
Their existence provides strong support for the hypothesis that "the surface of Alpha Centauri A is shaped by the magnetic activity driven by the generator processes within the convective zone."

We proposed a Gaussian basis Monte Carlo method to study the ground state of mobile electronic systems with strong correlations. This method is based on the variational principle, with the trial wave function represented as a product of Gutzwiller-Jastrow factors.
The proposed method can be applied to any type of electronic structure calculation method, such as density functional theory (DFT) or quantum Monte Carlo methods (QMC).
We have demonstrated that our method still performs well even when we use DFT results as input data instead of QMC results.
Additionally, it allows us to directly calculate physical quantities that are directly related to the relevant effects, without the need for complex numerical processes.
As an example application, we demonstrate how to use this method to study the magnetic properties of strongly correlated materials.
Our method will provide useful information about the magnetic properties of these materials.
This work was supported by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS KAKENHI) under grant number JP16K05481.
In this work, we propose a cooperative transmission protocol for wireless networks that utilizes multi-user detection (MUD) at relay nodes to improve spectral efficiency and diversity order.
The proposed scheme is based on network coding technology, allowing multiple users in the system to share the same time-frequency resources by leveraging spatial reuse gains.

We first consider an amplify-and-forward protocol in which each user simultaneously sends signals through different antennas, while the relay performs multi-user detection (MUD) before forwarding the signals to all other users.
Then, we will analyze the extension to the decode-forward scheme, which allows us to achieve higher data transmission rates than the amplify-forward scheme.
Finally, we derived closed-form expressions for the outage probability and ergodic capacity under the Rayleigh fading channel.
Our results indicate that the proposed solution can significantly improve spectrum efficiency and diversity order compared to traditional non-cooperative systems.
In addition, they also indicated that when the number of transmitting antennas increases, the performance gap between the two considered cooperative schemes is negligible.
Keywords: Cooperative communication; Amplify-and-forward protocol; Decode-and-forward scheme.

The Kondo chain model describes a chain in which the magnetic impurities are coupled to each other through antiferromagnetic exchange interaction J.
It was originally introduced to describe the physics of heavy fermion compounds, but it also naturally appears in other contexts.
In this study, we consider the case where the coupling constant J exceeds a certain critical value.
Jc = 2t / U, where t represents the transition amplitude between adjacent positions, and U represents the local Coulomb repulsion energy.

At subzero temperatures, the ground state of the system corresponds to a ferromagnetically ordered state, whereas at finite temperatures, it is expected that a continuous quantum phase transition occurs, transitioning to a paramagnetic state.
This transition occurs due to strong spin fluctuations, and therefore belongs to the same universality class as the Heisenberg chain.

However, there are significant differences between these two models: first, the Kondo chain includes two types of excitations—spinons and holons—while the Heisenberg chain is composed solely of spin-1/2 particles.
Secondly, the Kondo necklace includes additional degrees of freedom associated with charge carriers. 30-32.
These features have led to the observation of new phenomena not previously seen in the Heisenberg chain.

We present new observations and analyses of neutral hydrogen (HI) disks surrounding isolated galaxies, using data from the Very Large Array (VLA).
We have observed 12 nearby galaxies at a wavelength of 21 centimeters to determine their total HI mass and its distribution within the optical disk.
The sample includes late-type spiral galaxies and dwarf irregular galaxies.
Our results show that, with the exception of one galaxy, all galaxies have an extended HI halo that surpasses their optical radius; this is also true for gas-rich systems like NGC 4254 and NGC 5253.

Unfortunately, many people who have not received scientific training may not think like physicists; they tend to make mistakes that often lead them astray.

BaFeO3 is one of the most promising cathode materials for solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs).
In this study, we performed first-principles density functional theory calculations to investigate its electronic and magnetic properties in detail.
We found that it has a large spin polarization at the Fermi level and exhibits a metallic ground state.
The calculated band gap between the valence band and the conduction band is 0.2 electron volts, which is very consistent with the previous experimental results.
Our calculations indicate that there are two Fe-3d orbitals crossing the Fermi level, suggesting that both Fe3+ and Fe4+ ions are present in the compound.

In this work, we studied the throughput capacity region of multi-hop wireless networks with multiple transmitters and one receiver (MISO-MHWN).
We first clarify that MISO-MHWN is equivalent to an interference channel, where each transmitter has only one antenna but can communicate simultaneously with all receivers in the network.

We propose a causal inference method for longitudinal data based on Marginal Structural Models (MSMs), which is constrained by past treatments and the history of covariates. We refer to this as "history-constrained" MSMs.
We demonstrated how these models can be used to estimate the average effects during periods when treatment was not applied or outcomes were not observed.

Our proposed method is illustrated through two examples involving missing data: in one example, there are no unobserved confounding factors, but some subjects lack outcome information; in the other example, both the missing outcome information and unmeasured confounding factors affect the estimation.
The first example indicates that when all relevant variables have been measured, the estimates provided by our proposed method are similar to those obtained under complete follow-up.
On the contrary, the second example illustrates how standard methods may produce biased results due to incomplete outcome information or unmeasured confounding factors.
Finally, we provided simulation evidence showing that our proposed method still performs well even if the underlying model assumptions are not fully satisfied.
Keywords: marginal structural model, longitudinal data analysis

Introduction: The discovery of exoplanets has provided us with new insights into how planetary systems form and evolve.
However, most exoplanets are discovered through indirect techniques, such as the transit photometry method or Doppler spectroscopy.
These methods only provide information about the orbital parameters of the planets, while direct imaging offers additional constraints on their physical characteristics.
Especially, high-contrast imaging allows us to measure the mass of companions even at very low flux ratios relative to their host stars.
In recent years, significant progress has been made in achieving high-contrast imaging capabilities, which is essential for detecting Earth-like planets around nearby stars.
For example, the Gemini Planet Imager (GPI; Macintosh et al., 2014), SPHERE (Beuzit et al., 2008), and SCExAO (Jovanovic et al., 2015) instruments will soon begin operations on 8-10 meter telescopes.
These facilities provide unprecedented sensitivity and angular resolution, enabling them to detect regions closer to the central star, where terrestrial planets are more likely to exist.
However, these observatories operate under different conditions and utilize different technologies, so it is still unclear what performance they will achieve once they are put into operation.

We present a study on the ages derived from the method of gyrochronology for a sample of open star clusters with known ages (from the literature), aiming to assess the reliability of this method and its potential associated systematic biases.

This bias may be due to our use of only one rotation period for each star, which does not take into account any scattering or distribution of the observed periods among stars of the same age.
The results presented here indicate that if all relevant sources of uncertainty are carefully considered when applying this technology, it can provide useful constraints on stellar ages.

1 Introduction: The age of celestial bodies plays a crucial role in many fields of astrophysics, from galactic archaeology to exoplanet science.
Especially, accurate ages are crucial for understanding how planets form and evolve over time.
However, determining the precise age of a single star remains challenging, as they span multiple orders of magnitude in mass and brightness, and exhibit complex evolutionary histories.

For example, although the age of main sequence stars can be accurately determined using photometric techniques, such as fitting theoretical isochrones to color-magnitude diagrams (CMDs), these methods are difficult to easily extend beyond the red giant branch because the effects of convection become significant in that region.

Moreover, even if asteroseismology allows us to detect the interiors of evolved stars, interpreting the resulting data requires detailed modeling of the structure and evolution of each individual star.
Therefore, it is necessary to explore other methods to determine the ages of large samples of celestial bodies at different stages of evolution.

We present the results of two different models of galaxy formation: one is a stable model without dark matter halo merging or mass increase (the standard CDM scenario), and the other is an unstable model where dark matter halos continuously merge to form larger structures.
We use these models to study how galaxies evolve over time, as they are influenced by the merging of host dark matter halos.
The merging rate is higher in the early stages because there are more small halos available to merge into larger halos.
In our unstable model, we found that most massive galaxies have undergone several major mergers since z = 1, while lower mass galaxies have experienced fewer mergers.
Our results show that since z=1, the number density of the brightest galaxy clusters has significantly increased due to the merger of galaxy clusters.
This increase can be explained by the idea that the brightest star cluster galaxies grow through mergers, rather than solely forming from the cooling of gas in hot star cluster environments.

Gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are the most energetic explosions in the universe, but their origins remain unknown.
The main model for the production of gamma-ray bursts (GRB) involves the merger of two compact objects into a black hole, which then leads to an explosion due to rapid accretion onto this black hole.
In this talk, I will discuss how we can use gravitational waves to test this hypothesis by observing the ringdown phase of these merger events.
This is an exciting moment for gravitational wave astronomy, as advanced LIGO/VIRGO is about to begin data collection!
I will also introduce some of the latest results regarding the study of neutron star mergers that may be related to short gamma-ray bursts using gravitational waves.
Finally, I will give you my personal opinion on what it takes to become a successful scientist today.
My research interests include gravitational waves, astrophysics, cosmology, and particle physics.
I am currently working at the Kavli Institute for Astrophysics and Space Research at MIT, participating in the gravitational wave cosmology project.
We present the results of a large-scale spectral survey of active galactic nuclei (AGN) in the Southern Hemisphere using the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS).

The main goal is to select a complete sample of radio-strong active galactic nuclei (AGN) with flux limit for redshift z < 0.7 by cross-referencing the FIRST 1.4 GHz radio source catalog with the SDSS DR3 photometric database, which we refer to as ROXA (Radio-Optical Extragalactic Astronomy).
We have obtained spectra of over 1,000 celestial bodies in an area of approximately 10,000 square degrees.
In this work, we report the selection criteria used to define our samples, as well as their integrity and reliability.
We also discussed some preliminary results regarding the properties of these celestial bodies, such as their luminosity function and redshift distribution.
The project is funded by the European Space Agency, with contract number 4000106131/16/NL/PA.

The thermal stability and melting behavior of metallic single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) were studied using an efficient tight-binding molecular dynamics simulation method with the Tersoff potential function.
The results indicate that single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) can melt within a temperature range of 2000 to 3000 K, with the specific temperature depending on their diameter.
The study found that regardless of whether the pipes are serrated or armchair types, the melting temperature increases as the diameter decreases.
In addition, research indicates that the melting process involves two stages: first, the wall of the tube becomes disordered, and then a liquid-like structure forms within the tube.

Finally, we found that the melting point of SWCNTs has a strong dependence on the chirality index n-m. For example, when n-m changes from 0 to 1 or -1, the melting point of zigzag SWCNTs rises rapidly.
Keywords: thermal stability, melting behavior, carbon nanotubes

We indicate that these results can be derived using standard statistical mechanics techniques applied to systems with time-reversal symmetry breaking interactions.

This result is used to calculate the entropy production rate associated with several simple models, including Brownian motion, Langevin dynamics, and driven harmonic oscillators.

We assess the predictive capabilities of these models by comparing the predictions of galaxy formation models for the static optical luminosity functions (LFs) with observational results in the redshift range of z=2-3.

We use two different semi-analytical models, GALFORM and L-GALAXIES, to predict the evolution of galaxy number density in this redshift range, as well as the distribution of stellar mass and star formation rate of galaxies.
The predicted LF is directly compared with the observational data obtained using the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) on the Hubble Space Telescope.
In addition, we compared the distributions of the observed and predicted absolute magnitudes in the ultraviolet and the dust-corrected colors.

Our results show that both models can reproduce the overall shape of the observed luminosity function, but their normalized predictions are lower than the actual values, underestimating by as much as a factor of three.
If we assume that most faint galaxies are missed due to the shortcomings of the current survey, then this difference can largely be explained.

We conducted extensive research on the modal stability characteristics of the Delta Scuti (δ Sct) pulsating stars, based on theoretical and observational results obtained from open star clusters with ages ranging from 1 million to 2 billion years.

We conducted detailed non-radial stellar oscillation calculations using state-of-the-art evolutionary models, which include an extended treatment of convective boundaries and microscopic diffusion processes.
The main objective is to study how the observed frequency patterns change during the evolutionary process due to the effects of mixing and chemical composition gradients caused by rotation.
We pay special attention to the so-called mixed mode that is trapped in the overlapping region between the hydrogen-burning shell and the helium core.
These patterns exhibit very typical characteristics, such as large fluctuations and high non-linearity.
Our results indicate that these modes can be excited through turbulent pressure fluctuations associated with the convection zone near the surface layer of the star.
In addition, they also suggest that the excitation mechanisms may undergo significant changes as stars evolve from the main sequence stage to higher luminosities.

The human genome is composed of coding sequences (CDSs), which encode proteins; non-coding sequences (NCSs), which are transcribed but not translated into protein products; and introns, which are removed during the splicing process to ultimately produce mature mRNA.
Most non-coding sequences (NCS) have been shown to regulate gene expression at the transcriptional level through epigenetic mechanisms such as histone modifications or chromatin remodeling.

In addition, we have discovered a new principle that reveals the foundation of the evolution of NCSs (Neural Control Systems): the evolutionary process tends to increase the complexity of NCSs until they reach a maximum point, beyond which further increases in complexity lead to a decline in adaptability.
This discovery suggests that there is a universal law governing how living organisms evolve adaptively.
