We report strong electron-phonon interactions (EPI) observed in heavily boron-doped epitaxial graphene grown on SiC(0001).

The enhancement of EPI is more than an order of magnitude greater than that observed in undoped graphene, which can be attributed to the formation of the Dirac point at high doping levels and its associated van Hove singularity near the Fermi level.
This finding suggests that the carrier concentration in doped graphene can be modulated by several orders of magnitude through chemical or electrostatic means.
Graphene has garnered significant attention due to its unique physical properties, such as extremely high carrier mobility and very large optical nonlinearity.
However, these remarkable characteristics are often accompanied by weak interactions between electrons and phonons, which limits their application in high-speed electronics and optoelectronics.

In this work, we demonstrate that the EPI (electron-phonon interaction) in heavily boron-doped epitaxial graphene grown by thermal decomposition of SiC can be significantly enhanced due to the presence of Dirac points near the Fermi level (EF) and the related van Hove singularities.
We indicate that when the Fermi level crosses the Van Hove singularity, the EPI increases rapidly, leading to a huge increase in the electron-phonon scattering rate.

Our research results indicate that the electron-phonon coupling (EPI) in graphene can be electrically controlled through chemical or electrostatic gates, thereby opening new directions for novel devices based on graphene.
Graphene is known for its extremely high carrier mobility, but its electron-phonon coupling is relatively small.
These two competing effects determine the performance of graphene-based electronic and optoelectronic devices.
For example, a low EPI leads to slow relaxation rates, which limits the operating speed of graphene transistors.
On the other hand, the high mobility makes graphene particularly attractive for applications in high-speed electronics and ultrafast photodetectors.
Therefore, the development of methods to enhance EPI while maintaining high liquidity has attracted great interest.
We present the results of radio emission analysis of supernova remnant (SNR) 1987A, which is predominantly dominated by two bright sources located on opposite sides of the shell.
The first source is consistent with a pulsar wind nebula driven by a newly born neutron star; its spectrum peaks at around 1 GHz and extends to about 10 GHz.
The second source was recently discovered, and as an extended feature, it seems to be associated with the reverse shock front generated during the explosion.
Its spectrum peaks between 5 and 8 GHz, and there is no evidence of spectral turnover at 20 GHz.

We interpret this source as synchrotron radiation emitted by relativistic electrons that are accelerated by the forward shock wave driven by the expanding shock wave generated during a supernova explosion, with these electrons being accelerated as they move through the interstellar medium.
Through addition, we find evidence suggesting the existence of another emission component with a peak close to 3 GHz, but its source remains unclear.
Finally, we report the detection results of circularly polarized radiation from two components.

We propose that the energy release process in coronal mass ejections (CMEs) occurs due to two different physical mechanisms: magnetic reconnection and catastrophic loss of equilibrium caused by ideal magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) instabilities.
The first mechanism converts the stored free magnetic energy into the kinetic energy of plasma flow during coronal solar flare events (such as flares or coronal mass ejections).

This mechanism has been extensively studied through numerical simulations based on magnetohydrodynamic models with varying levels of complexity, ranging from simple two-dimensional configurations to more realistic three-dimensional configurations.
In this work, we focus on the second mechanism, which involves the rapid conversion of magnetic field energy into thermal energy through explosive restructuring of magnetic topology.
We demonstrated how to analyze and model this mechanism within the framework of ideal magnetohydrodynamics theory.
Our results indicate that these two processes may occur simultaneously, but at different evolutionary stages of the eruptive flow.

We propose new exact solutions to the Einstein field equations for stationary axisymmetric spacetimes with two commuting Killing vectors. These solutions are generated by applying non-equilibrium framework transformations (NFT) to known vacuum solutions.

We use these observations to test the relationship between general relativity and alternative theories of gravity, which predict deviations from general relativity in regions of high curvature, such as near black holes or neutron stars.
Specifically, we consider scalar-tensor theories, in which the coupling between the matter fields and the metric is mediated by a light scalar field.
The motivation for these theories comes from string theory and has been widely researched for decades.
For each event, we perform Bayesian model selection using simulated signals generated from general relativity and several representative scalar-tensor theories.
Our results indicate that there is no evidence of deviations from general relativity within the current range of uncertainty.

We study the evolution of coronal mass ejections (CMEs) through three-dimensional magnetohydrodynamic simulations that include ideal magnetohydrodynamic effects and resistivity.
The construction of the initial conditions is as follows.
First, we solve the Grad-Shafranov equation under the condition of no pressure balance to obtain the polar coordinate current density distribution on the surface of the toroidal structure.
Then we assume that the toroidal structure has a uniform temperature of T = 1 MK and a pressure of P = 0.1 dyn cm^-2 within its volume, and we proceed to construct a 3D model.

We also assume that there are two types of plasma flowing along the magnetic field lines: one is a slow solar wind flowing outward from the bottom boundary at r = 2 R_sun, where R_sun represents the radius of the Sun, and the other is a fast solar wind flowing inward from the top boundary at r = 20 R_sun.
Finally, we add random fluctuations to the velocity field, making its kinetic energy comparable to the thermal energy.
In our simulation, we found that there are three distinct stages in the evolution process of the CME (Coronal Mass Ejection).
In the first stage, the magnetic flux rope rises slowly due to the Lorentz force associated with the azimuthal component of the magnetic field.

At around 50 minutes, when the height reaches about 5 solar radii, the ascent motion suddenly accelerates. This is due to the magnetic reconnection between the open magnetic field lines surrounding the flux rope and the closed loops, which leads to a rapid expansion of the cross-section of the flux rope.
This acceleration continues until the flux rope reaches the upper boundary at about 80 minutes.
In the second stage, the magnetic flux tube rapidly expands outward while maintaining its shape.
However, when reaching the maximum size (around 90 minutes), the flux rope starts to contract inward again.
Therefore, the magnetic flux rope has become thinner than before, but it still maintains its twisted structure.
Meanwhile, the surrounding open magnetic field lines become more curved around the center of the magnetic field line rope.
These results indicate that the flux rope experiences a torsional instability after expanding outward beyond its critical size.

In order to achieve unconditional security against eavesdropping attacks, Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) requires both parties to measure single photons generated at remote locations.
In recent years, significant progress has been made in the commercialization of Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) systems.

The XMM-SSC catalog contains over 100,000 serendipitously discovered X-ray sources, which were extracted from all publicly available data obtained by the European Space Agency's XMM-Newton satellite during the first three years of its operation.
It covers almost the entire sky visible in Europe, located above |b| > 10 degrees.
The X-ray survey provides a large sample of active galactic nuclei (AGN) that can be statistically studied across a wide range of brightness, redshift, and other parameters.
However, due to the possibility of displaying complex spectral shapes and/or varying over multiple time scales, it is often difficult to clearly identify individual sources.

In order to select a complete sample of active galactic nuclei with extreme characteristics, we applied very strict selection criteria based on the source count rate and photon index measured in the 0.5-2 keV band.
The choice of these standards is aimed at maximizing the proportion of absorbed sources while keeping the contamination caused by background fluctuations low.
Our final sample consists of 56 sources, including four known blazars.

We reported the detection of gamma-ray burst (GRB) 060927 by Swift/BAT and Konus-Wind, which is one of only two events to date with a redshift greater than five.
The redshift was determined using optical spectra obtained with the Very Large Telescope in Chile within three hours after the trigger time of the explosion.
We found that the event has a very hard spectrum, similar to other high-redshift bursts observed previously.

Based on our current understanding of the physics behind these phenomena, we estimate that the total energy released during the instantaneous radiation phase of the explosion is on the order of 10^53 erg.

We demonstrated the first detection of secondary cosmic microwave background polarization in galaxy clusters caused by Faraday rotation (FR), using data obtained from the Atacama Cosmology Telescope polarimeter (ACTPol).
We detected polarization emission caused by FR at angular scales corresponding to the multipole feature = 100-1000, involving two galaxy clusters: ACT-CL J0102-4915 and ACT-CL J0546-5345.
The observed signals are consistent with the theoretical predictions based on numerical simulations of magnetized star cluster atmospheres.

This measurement provides an important test for our understanding of the magnetic fields in galaxy clusters and their impact on cosmological observations, such as the temperature anisotropies of the cosmic microwave background radiation and E-mode polarization.

In addition, we report the upper limits of polarized radiation caused by FR from other galaxy clusters that have not been individually detected due to low signal-to-noise ratios or limited survey areas.
These results will be very useful for future studies of the CMB polarization maps generated by upcoming experiments regarding the FR effect, such as the Planck satellite and the Simons Observatory.

The detection of exoplanets is one of the most exciting developments in astronomy in recent times, but the characterization of these planets is still incomplete.
The goal of this paper is to develop new techniques for characterizing exoplanetary systems using dynamical methods.

Specifically, I studied how to understand the formation history of planetary systems by measuring the mass distribution of small bodies (planetary embryos) that are in a state of mean motion resonance with planets, using the planets as detectors.
My first project studied the effect of planetary particle size on the stability of planetary orbits.
Through numerical simulations, we found that smaller stars cause planetary orbits to become unstable more quickly than larger stars, because they have higher orbital eccentricity.
This result suggests that there may be an upper limit to the planetary embryos formed during the process of planetary migration.
My second project studied the impact of mutual inclination between planets on the stability of planetary systems.
We have demonstrated that when two planets are locked in a 2:1 resonance, mutual inclination increases the likelihood of instability.
Finally, my third project explores the possibility of detecting terrestrial planets around white dwarfs through gravitational microlensing events.

This research is dedicated to studying the wave dynamics of photons in the form of position characteristic vectors, which are introduced as solutions to the photon Schrödinger equation with arbitrary energy spectra.
The concept of position eigenvector allows people to describe the state of a single photon using the position probability density distribution function (PDF).
It also allows us to introduce the concept of quantum trajectories to describe the evolution of the probability density function over time.
Specifically, we demonstrate that quantum trajectories corresponding to different initial states can be obtained from each other through unitary transformations.
We demonstrate how to use these results to analyze various phenomena related to the propagation of light in dispersive media.
Finally, we discussed the potential applications of our method in describing non-classical effects related to the emission of entangled photon pairs.

1 Introduction.
Seismology plays an important role in understanding the physical processes related to earthquakes.

Since Aki (1957) introduced it into seismology, the traditional method for calculating the cumulative energy released by earthquakes has become one of the most popular techniques among seismologists and geophysical researchers.

However, does this method have some issues, such as: i) the need to accurately determine the epicenter location before analysis; ii) the results are highly dependent on the choice of time window length; iii) it cannot provide sufficient information about the earthquake source mechanism.
To overcome these difficulties, many attempts have recently been made to develop new tools for analyzing seismic data.
For example, Sato et al. (1989), Kao and Chen (1990), Wu and Chiao (1991a, 1991b), and Wu (1993) developed different methods to calculate the cumulative energy release rate.
The authors found that the results are not always consistent due to the differences in the assumptions they adopted.

We conducted high angular resolution observations (0.1′′) of the typical massive star formation region G29.96-0.02 using a submillimeter wave array (SMA). The observations included dust continuum emission, molecular line emissions, and micromaser lines.
The SMA data shows that the source consists of two compact components that are 0.3" apart, and these two components are associated with different physical processes.
A component shows strong thermal dust emission, with a peak at 345 GHz, and is surrounded by intense methanol masers distributed along a structure resembling an arc.
This component spatially coincides with a bright infrared source detected by the Spitzer Space Telescope.
We suggest that this component represents a hot core, where massive star formation occurs.
Another component exhibits a weak dust continuum emission, but strong SiO (5-4), SO2 (34-26), CH3OH (7-6), and CH3CN (12-11) lines.
These results suggest that the component may be tracing shock regions driven by jets or outflows produced by young stellar objects embedded in a hot core.

The Zero-locus Theorem is an important theorem in algebraic geometry, which states that if a system of polynomial equations has no solutions over a certain field, then it must have at least one solution in the algebraic closure of that field.
From this work, we demonstrate how to use the zero-point theorem as part of a general framework to represent combinatorial optimization problems (COPs) as systems of polynomial equations.
We demonstrate our approach on several combinatorial optimization problems (COPs), including maximum clique, minimum vertex cover, and maximum independent set.
This research was supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF) under grant number CCF-0430020.
The author appreciates the valuable suggestions provided by Professor David Avis and Professor Michael Schmeilis during the preparation of this manuscript.
The zero-point theorem provides a powerful tool for solving certain types of computational problems that can be expressed as polynomial equations.

It points out that if such a system has no solution in a given field K, then there is at least one solution in the algebraic closure of K. In this paper, we propose a general method for converting combinatorial optimization problems into polynomial equations, which allows us to utilize the zero-point theorem to determine their solvability.
Our method relies on representing each feasible solution of the COP as a point in a vector space \( V \) with an appropriate inner product.
Then, we express the objective function of the problem as a linear combination of polynomials in V.
Finally, we formulate the problem as a system of polynomial equations, requiring all points corresponding to feasible solutions to simultaneously satisfy the objective function.
As an example, we apply our technology to three well-known NP-hard combinatorial optimization problems: maximum clique, minimum vertex cover, and maximum independent set.

Introduction: In recent years, several massive exoplanets with orbital periods of less than four days have been discovered.

These short-period planets are particularly interesting because they may be tidally locked, resulting in a synchronous rotation with their axis, which would lead to significant day-night contrasts on their surfaces.
Additionally, the atmospheres of these planets may experience extreme conditions due to high temperatures and intense radiation fields.

Therefore, understanding how planetary atmospheres respond in these situations can provide us with important insights to help us understand the processes occurring in our own solar system as well as in other planetary systems.

Through follow-up observations using the Spitzer Space Telescope, we show that the orbit of TrES-3b is relatively close to its host star, thus tidal forces should synchronize the planet's rotational axis with its orbital angular momentum vector.

However, we did not detect significant infrared excess emission associated with the planet or its host star, indicating that the planet either does not have a large amount of dust material surrounding it, or that the temperature of the planet is too low to produce detectable thermal emission above 4 micrometers.

We consider the problem of the time evolution of quantum fields in the Milne universe, which is an open Friedmann-Robertson-Walker (FRW) universe with negative spatial curvature and a vanishing cosmological constant.
We demonstrate that, at early moments (t → −∞), there is no normalized solution corresponding to the Klein-Gordon equation for massive particles.
This result can be understood as follows.
The Milne universe has a singularity at t = 0, at which point all physical quantities diverge.
Specifically, the energy density diverges like \( 1/t^2 \) near that point.
Therefore, any particle state localized near \( t=0 \) will possess infinite energy.
Therefore, it cannot correspond to a physically meaningful solution of the field equations.
On the other hand, we found that there are normalized state descriptions of early massless particles.
These states represent the past propagation of gravitons or photons along geodesics towards the singularity of the big bang in the spacetime geometry.

We present the results of our analysis of galaxy-galaxy lensing data for three different types of dark matter halos, using millennium simulations and semi-analytical models to predict their characteristics.
We found that early-type galaxies are aligned along filaments, while late-type galaxies show no alignment signals at all.
The intermediate type shows some evidence indicating an arrangement perpendicular to the filament structure.
These findings can be explained by the effect of tidal torques, which play a role when gas enters a halo potential, having a more significant impact on early-type galaxies than on late-type galaxies.
This effect may also explain why we do not observe any significant alignment between the shapes of dark matter halos.
Our results indicate that the observed galaxy arrangement may be caused by large-scale gravitational fields, rather than primordial effects.
In this work, we studied how the shape of dark matter halos affects the distribution of satellite galaxies around them.
Through N-body simulations, we investigate whether there is a correlation between the orientation of the host halo's principal axis and the position angle of the satellite relative to it.
We found that this correlation exists only when the mass ratio between the primary and secondary halos is sufficiently large (M1/M2 > 10).
For smaller mass ratios, the directions of the halos of the two become independent due to dynamic friction.

We use the density matrix renormalization group (DMRG) method to study the temperature-driven phase transitions of different charge ordered states in the one-dimensional quarter-filled Hubbard model with nearest-neighbor hopping and onsite Coulomb repulsion.
We found that at low temperatures, the system is in a Wigner crystal state, where electrons become localized due to strong electron correlation.

With the increase in temperature, we observed a first-order phase transition into a charged density wave state, which has been theoretically predicted for a long time but has not yet been observed experimentally.
The essence of this phase transition can be understood as the melting of the Wigner crystal caused by thermal fluctuations.
Finally, we also studied the effect of the next nearest neighbor hopping \( t' \) on these phases.
Our results indicate that for small t′ values, the ground state remains in the Wigner crystal phase, while for large t′ values, it becomes a metallic phase.
This indicates that the next nearest transition may disrupt charge ordering in a one-dimensional system.

We present new observations of the central region of the nearby Seyfert galaxy NGC 4258, which indicate that its nuclear disk is twisted by approximately 20 degrees relative to the plane of the stellar bulge of the host galaxy (see Figure 1).
The distortion has been detected through near-infrared integral field spectral observations obtained at the Gemini Observatory on Mauna Kea, Hawaii.

We present optical to infrared multi-band measurements for 12 giant galaxies (with mass M* > 10^11 Msun) within the redshift range of 1.9 < z < 2.7, selected based on their original ultraviolet colors as analogs of Lyman break galaxies.

We used the near-infrared spectrograph (NIRSPEC) of the Keck telescope to conduct deep near-infrared spectral measurements of these celestial objects in order to determine their stellar masses, finding that their masses range between 3 x 10^11 and 5 x 10^11 solar masses.
Most of our targets show strong evidence of starburst activity based on their high effective widths.
The [OIII] emission lines and the larger Balmer decrement suggest the presence of dust in the star-forming region.
Using Spitzer/IRAC photometry, we found that most of these systems have red mid-infrared colors, which is consistent with the expected evolutionary stellar populations.
However, our two sources seem to be bluer than this trend, indicating that they may contain a significant amount of obscured active galactic nucleus (AGN) activity.

We studied the electron spin relaxation rates of gold-palladium alloys with different compositions at low temperatures (T < 1 K) through pulse neutrino spin rotation and relaxation measurements, where T1e-1/T1e = 1/(1 + T2e).

The results indicate that the relaxation rate observed at high temperatures is consistent with the predictions of the Elliott-Yafet scattering mechanism, but it deviates significantly below 0.5 K. We find that this deviation can be explained if we assume there is an additional contribution to the relaxation rate due to spin-orbit interactions between the conducting electrons and the localized magnetic moments associated with palladium atoms.

This is supported by our theoretical calculations based on density functional theory, which predict that the spin-orbit coupling strength will significantly increase as one moves away from the center of the Brillouin zone towards the Fermi surface.

Our research results indicate that the presence of local magnetic moments may play an important role in determining the transport properties of these materials, even when they do not exhibit magnetic order at the measured lowest temperatures.

We have conducted near-infrared (NIR) polarization observations of the GG Tau system, and the results show that its circumstellar disk structure is complex, consisting of several bright regions with different polarization characteristics.
The most significant feature in our dataset is the arc-like structure located about 0.5 arcseconds southeast of the binary star center.
The region exhibits strong polarized radiation, with an intensity reaching up to 10% of the total intensity, and has been previously identified as a reflection nebula by Weintraub et al. (1993).
We found that this feature can be explained by scattering from optically thin dust particles near the midplane of the disk.
In addition, we detected two other bright features on both sides of the central binary star.
These are also related to a high degree of linear polarization, but there is no obvious evidence of scattered light.
On the contrary, they seem to be caused by absorption under the background stellar flux.
Finally, we identified three additional darker structures in the southern part of the disk.
All of these features have similar polarization angles, indicating that their origins may be related.

We studied the diameter and clustering coefficient of several types of random graphs with power-law degree distributions, including preferential attachment (PA) networks.
We demonstrate that if the growth of the PA network is slow enough, it has a small diameter; this result still holds even in the case where multiple edges between nodes are allowed.
However, there are some examples indicating that for rapidly growing PA networks, the diameter grows exponentially as a function of n.
In addition to studying the diameter, we also consider the clustering coefficient of these networks.
The clustering coefficient measures the degree of connectivity between a node's neighbors.
We proved the upper bound of the clustering coefficient of PA networks, which holds regardless of the rate at which new nodes join the network.
Finally, we present some numerical results that demonstrate our theoretical predictions are in excellent agreement with the simulation results.

We analyzed the Bondi accretion rate of primordial black holes (PBHs) during the radiation-dominated era, taking into account the effects of pressure and viscosity on gas flow.

We found that for PBH mass \( M \gg 10^{10} \) g, the Bondi radius is much larger than the Schwarzschild radius, so the standard Bondi-Hoyle-Lyttleton formula can be used to calculate the accretion rate.
In smaller mass micro black holes (M < 10^(10)g), we use numerical simulations to determine the time-varying accretion rate.
The results were compared with those obtained under the assumption that the pressure or viscosity of the accumulated gas can be neglected.

We have proposed an accurate and efficient fundamental measure density functional (FMT) method to describe fluids composed of rigidly aligned hard hexagons, which serve as a model system of significant importance for liquid crystals or colloidal suspensions with anisotropic interactions.

Our results indicate that the VT method can be successfully applied to identify galaxy clusters, even when only photometric redshifts are available.
In this work, we have identified over 12,000 galaxy clusters in the range of 0 < z < 0.3.
These galaxy groups contain approximately 30,000 member galaxies.
We also provide a catalog that includes basic information about all these groups, such as their location, size, color, and luminosity redshift.
Keywords: Galaxy clusters, luminosity redshift.
We report on the first simultaneous infrared and X-ray observations of Sagittarius A* made with the Chandra X-ray Observatory and the Spitzer Space Telescope from 2007 to 2008.

We found that the emission of infrared radiation is consistent with the results produced by dust heated to temperatures between 100 K and 1000 K; this temperature range corresponds to the flux density range of 0.1 mJy to 1 Jy observed at 8 micrometers.
The spectral index of infrared radiation did not show significant changes during these processes.
This result indicates that the physical conditions in the launch area are relatively constant over a timescale as short as one month.
These results also indicate that infrared radiation may be primarily dominated by optically thin thermal bremsstrahlung rather than by synchrotron radiation.

It is predicted that black holes produce strong electromagnetic fields near their event horizons.
However, direct observational evidence is still difficult to obtain due to the extreme environment surrounding these objects.
One possible method to detect such fields is by detecting the polarized light emitted near the horizon.
Another possibility involves detecting the spectral or intensity variations of the accretion flow of the black hole itself.
Such a change may occur if the magnetic field lines passing through the disc become twisted into a spiral shape due to differential rotation.
If this is the case, they can amplify any waves coming along them like an antenna.

We presented the results of our study on the physical properties of weak Mg II absorbers (WAs) in quasar spectra, using high-resolution spectroscopy and photoionization modeling.

We found that WAs are usually associated with galaxies that have a stellar mass M* ~ 10^10 to 10^11 solar masses, a star formation rate (SFR) of 0.1-10 solar masses per year, and a metallicity Z of 0.2 - 1 times solar metallicity.
Most of these systems have a low ionization parameter log U < -2.5, which suggests that they might be primarily composed of diffuse gas rather than dense clumps.
These findings suggest that WAs may be related to the galactic winds driven from star-forming regions.

Moreover, we found evidence for two different populations of WAs; one population is characterized by relatively strong absorption lines, which primarily originate from the halo of the galaxy, while the other population exhibits weaker absorption features that seem to originate from the central region of their host galaxies.
We propose a logic for reasoning about reachability properties on connected data structures, which are graphs with labeled nodes and edges, capable of being traversed using Web Link Language (WLL).
WLL is an extension of RDFS, allowing users to specify how applications create or modify links between resources.

We demonstrated how our logic can be used to express important types of queries related to linked data, such as finding all paths between two given nodes, calculating the distance between them, checking whether there is at least one path between them, etc., and we proved its decidability.
Finally, we provide algorithms for evaluating these queries under certain constraints.
Our results have been implemented in the LOD2 system.

This work is partially supported by the European Commission through the Seventh Framework Programme (FP7) project LOD2 (grant agreement number 258520) and by the Swiss National Science Foundation (SNF) grant number PP00P2-125231/1.

We present cosmological fluid dynamics simulations that track the formation of galaxy clusters in a pre-heating scenario, where gas is heated by the first generation of stars and subsequently collapses into dark matter halos.
We compared our results with the observed X-ray luminosity-temperature (L-T) relationship at z = 0 and the temperature distribution over a large radius range.
Our simulated L-T relationship closely matches the observational data across a range of three orders of magnitude in luminosity.
The observed L-T relationship has a steeper slope at lower temperatures, while we did not find such a trend in our simulations.
This difference may be due to additional heating mechanisms not included in our model, or it may be caused by systematic uncertainties in the observational sample.
In addition, we demonstrate that the entropy profile of the star cluster population we simulated can reproduce the shape of the observed profile within its range of dispersion.
However, significant differences exist between individual simulated star clusters and real systems, which may be caused by non-gravitational processes such as active galactic nucleus feedback.
We present the near-infrared (NIR) spectra and photometric measurements of HD 97048, an evolved star surrounded by a dust-rich interstellar environment and enveloped by a large debris disk.
The near-infrared spectrum shows strong emission lines of the H I Paschen series, as well as the Brackett γ line located at 2.166 microns.
We also detected a CO spectral band at approximately 2.3 microns, which is a characteristic feature of late-type stars.
Through addition, we find evidence of water vapor absorption bands near 1.4-1.8 microns, indicating the presence of warm water vapor within the system.

Using the newly acquired data and archival spectra, we derived several physical parameters, such as effective temperature T_eff = 8200 K, surface gravity log g = 3.9 dex, luminosity L = 4 × 10^6 L⊙, mass M = 5 M⊙, radius R = 6 R⊙, and age t = 7 × 10^7 years.
These values indicate whether the object belongs to the red giant branch phase and is progressing toward becoming a white dwarf.

We present multi-band polarization observations of fifteen active galactic nuclei (AGNs), conducted using the Very Large Array (VLA) and the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array (JVLA) between 5 and 43 GHz, including simultaneous measurements at two frequency bands for eight of the sources.
We found that most active galactic nuclei exhibit correlated polarization behavior within our frequency range; however, we also discovered several examples that do not conform to this pattern.
Specifically, we observed significant changes in fractional linear polarization over short time scales, as well as large discrepancies in position angles between different frequencies.
These results are consistent with previous studies, indicating that these celestial bodies change rapidly on small spatial scales.

Introduction: Recent research [1] indicates that the worldsheet sigma model (WSSM), through its connection with gravitational quantum integrals [2], provides a strong framework for studying quantum gravity.

One particularly interesting aspect of this method is that it allows for the direct calculation of perturbative corrections to the WSSM action from the gravitational path integral, without relying on explicit calculations involving gravitons or graviton loops.
In [4], it is suggested that WSSM can also be used to study the effective action under the flow of the renormalization group (RG).
However, due to the fact that WSSM has an infinite number of degrees of freedom, there is no finite-dimensional parameter space for RG flow to occur.
On the contrary, the RG flow must proceed along some infinite-dimensional trajectory in the space where all possible actions occur.
To better understand this trajectory, it would be beneficial to define a reasonable metric in the WSSM action space, so that the distances between different actions can be measured.
This measure should be able to determine whether two given actions are close or distant in all possible WSSM spaces.

We study the problem of reconstructing evolutionary history that includes reticulate events and vertical transmission, where reticulate events are represented by hybridization or horizontal gene transfer (HGT).
We demonstrate how to use the maximum reduction method to find the optimal solution to this problem in polynomial time when the degrees of all input trees are bounded.
This is achieved through a novel dynamic programming algorithm that calculates the minimum number of mesh events required to explain each group of classification units on each tree in the input set.

Our method is part of a larger approach that utilizes a collection of rooted bifurcating phylogenetic trees inferred from various types of data (such as DNA sequences, morphological traits, fossil records, etc.) to infer species networks, while it may also provide insights into the evolution of complex organisms such as viruses and bacteria.

Introduction: The reconstruction of evolutionary relationships among biological entities has always been one of the core problems in biology, since the publication of Darwin's "On the Origin of Species" 150 years ago.
The most widely accepted evolutionary model hypothesizes that new species evolve over time through vertical transmission — that is, they pass genetic material directly from parents to offspring.

However, in many cases, we cannot assume that evolution proceeds strictly vertically; instead, some form of horizontal gene transfer (HGT) occurs between two lineages, leading to what we call reticulate evolution.
For example, if a virus infects a bacterium, then its genes will be horizontally transmitted through the host cell membrane; similarly, if one plant hybridizes with another plant...
Then the offspring inherit genetic material from both parents.

The Galactic Center (GC) is one of the most fascinating regions in our galaxy, but its relatively close distance to the Sun has made it difficult to study.
GC contains many compact radio sources, which are believed to be associated with young pulsars or magnetars.
In this paper, we present the results of two surveys conducted with the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA) at a frequency of 1.4 GHz.
We observed the central region of the Milky Way for about 100 hours during three periods between 2005 and 2007.
Our first survey covered a 2-degree region around the Sagittarius A* center.
This survey aims to search for new compact radio sources near the center of the galaxy, while also studying the properties of the diffuse radiation around Sagittarius A*.
Our second survey covered a larger area centered around the Galactic Center with a range of 4 degrees.
This survey aims to study the distribution of molecular gas toward the center of the galaxy by simultaneously observing the 12CO (J=1-0), 13CO (J=1-0), and C18O (J=1-0) lines.
When a spin system is subjected to two consecutive radiofrequency (RF) pulses, and there is an interval between the two pulses called the pulse separation time Tsep, a spin echo will be observed.

The first radiofrequency pulse generates a macroscopic magnetization vector M0, which precesses in the external magnetic field Bext at the Larmor frequency fL = γBext, where γ is the gyromagnetic ratio of the nuclear spin.

After the second radiofrequency pulse, the flip angle of the pulse is θ2, and the phase shift relative to the first pulse is φ2. The transverse component of the magnetization vector M2(t) decays exponentially due to dephasing caused by the local magnetic field generated by neighboring nuclei.
In this work, we demonstrate how to generate spin echoes using strong π pulses, even in the absence of any initial net magnetization before the application of these pulses.
We have demonstrated both theoretically and experimentally that this spin echo essentially originates from the dipole interaction between nuclear spins.
We studied the second harmonic (SH) and third harmonic (TH) generation in an inhomogeneous wide cavity featuring two different fundamental resonant frequencies.

We indicate that when the intracavity FW light intensity reaches its maximum, both second harmonic generation (SHG) and third harmonic generation (THG) can be simultaneously enhanced by increasing the pump rate or decreasing the detuning between the two modes.
The reason for the enhancement is that, at this point, the nonlinear optical strain is greater than zero.
This effect has been observed in experiments recently.
In addition, we found another mechanism in which only one type of harmonic can be efficiently generated while suppressing other types of harmonics.

For example, if the FW field in the cavity is adjusted to be close to the lower mode frequency, it will mainly generate SH light, while almost not producing TH light; on the contrary, if the FW field in the cavity is adjusted to be close to the upper mode frequency, it will mainly generate TH light, while almost not producing SH light.
We analyzed the alignment between galaxy rotation and the tidal field in real space, using data from the Two-Mass Redshift Survey (TMRS).
We found that galaxies preferentially align vertically with their local tidal fields on scales greater than 1 Mpc/h.
This alignment is more pronounced in larger mass galaxies and at higher redshifts.
The observed spin-tidal correlation can be explained by the effects of gravitational torques exerted by large-scale structure during the formation of these galaxies.
Our results indicate that this mechanism may play an important role in shaping the angular momentum of galaxies.
These findings are important for understanding how dark matter halos acquire their angular momentum and for explaining cosmic shear statistical observations.
Introduction: Galaxies form in densely populated regions of the universe, where they experience strong gravitational interactions with other objects, such as nearby galaxies or galaxy clusters.
During the formation process, these interactions generate gravitational torques, thereby affecting the direction of the galactic angular momentum vector.
Conversely, the orientation of a galaxy's angular momentum determines the shape of the galaxy through dynamical friction processes.
Therefore, some have suggested that the shape distribution of galaxies can provide information about the origin of angular momentum in galaxies (e.g., Catelan & Theuns 1996; Lee et al. 2008).

However, observational studies show contradictory results, as there may be a preferred direction regarding the orientation of galaxy rotation axes relative to the positions of their neighbors (see, for example, Faltenbacher et al., 2002; Bailin et al., 2005; Paz et al., 2008; Codis et al., 2012 recent studies).

In order to understand the physical mechanisms that determine the direction of angular momentum in galaxies, we need to study the statistical properties of the spin distribution of galaxies on a cosmic large scale.
The recent Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) has enabled us to accurately measure the directions of galaxies, allowing for such analyses.
For example, Li et al. (2008) studied the alignment relationship between the galaxy spin vectors and the positions of their nearest neighbors using SDSS DR4 data.
They did not find it.
We proposed an automated method that uses machine learning techniques to classify supernova candidates in differential imaging data, and applied it to the Dark Energy Survey (DES).
DES is a five-year survey that uses a 1.2 square degree camera on the 4-meter Blanco telescope located at the Cerro Tololo International Observatory (CTIO) in Chile.

We used two different classification algorithms - Random Forest and Support Vector Machine - which were trained on simulated images generated by injecting artificial point sources into real DES images.
Our results indicate that when classifying objects as stars or galaxies, we can achieve high efficiency (>90%), high purity (>80%), and high completeness (>95%) within the range of iAB = 24 mag.
This enables us to discover more supernovae in a unit of time than with previous methods, while reducing human bias associated with visual inspection.
By increasing our capabilities, our technology allows us to identify new transient classes, such as tidal disruption events and microlensing flares.
We present recent near-infrared (NIR) spectral observations of the brightest member in the interacting galaxies NGC 7679/NGC 7682.
The NIR spectrum shows strong narrow forbidden lines and permitted lines typical of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) in the P Cygni profile.
We detected blue-shifted absorption components on both sides of the Hα and [N II] 6584 Å lines, which may be caused by an outflow driven by nuclear winds.
In addition, we found that the flux ratio between the two strongest optical emission lines observed is higher than the expected value based on the photoionization model.
This indicates that, in addition to the central engine, there may be other ionization sources, such as shock or collision heating.
Our results indicate that this celestial object can be classified as a composite Seyfert 2 galaxy, where the contribution of starburst activity to the total luminosity is significant.

We propose a method different from the conventional Feynman path integral description to calculate the probability amplitudes in quantum walk models, which is based on the concept of scattering states and their associated S-matrix elements.
We have demonstrated that this new formalism enables us to obtain accurate results for several interesting cases where the standard methods fail or are not applicable.

Specifically, we consider two different types of boundary conditions at one end of the chain (the origin), which leads to the system exhibiting completely different behaviors during the time evolution.

The first type is known as the Dirichlet boundary condition, which corresponds to reflecting the particle back to the origin after it leaves the origin; while the second case corresponds to absorbing the particle when it reaches the origin.
In both cases, we use our new method to accurately calculate the evolution operator for all \( t > 0 \).
Finally, by applying the inverse Fourier transform to the evolutionary operator, we can recover the complete probability distribution function of the walker at any position x on the chain at time t.

We present the numerical simulation results of the nonlinear evolution of electrostatic waves excited by a local source in a magnetized, collisionless plasma with non-uniform density and temperature distributions.
The initial conditions were chosen to be close to those observed in the large plasma device (LAPD) experiment at the University of California, Los Angeles.

We found that the spectrum is mainly dominated by two different branches, which correspond to different types of waves: the slow mode propagates along the magnetic field lines, while the fast mode propagates at an oblique angle relative to the magnetic field.

In addition, we have observed many other interesting phenomena, such as the generation of coherent structures and the formation of shock fronts, all of which can be explained within the framework of Zaharoff's Langmuir turbulence theory.
Keywords: Nonlinear dynamics; turbulence; wave-particle interaction; collisionless plasma; LAPD; fast-slow mode coupling; fluctuations.

We have proposed an analytical solution for the bending problem of thin elastic shells with variable thickness under surface loading. This solution is applicable to cases where the variation in shell thickness spans multiple orders of magnitude in the radial direction, and the load distribution is not necessarily axisymmetric.

We demonstrated that in this case, it is possible to achieve precise results using only two parameters, rather than the three parameters that were previously thought to be necessary (the third parameter being the ratio between the maximum and minimum values of the shell thickness).
The new formula allows us to calculate the deflection at any point on the surface of the shell without the need to solve additional equations or perform numerical integration.
This makes our algorithm much faster than previous methods while maintaining high accuracy.
Our method can be used to simulate the response of the crust to tectonic stress as well as to other processes such as volcanic loading and sediment deposition.
It also has applications in geophysics beyond Earth sciences, including planetary science, astrophysics, and seismology.

In order to study the deformation of the crust, we need to understand the variations of the stress field in different regions of the Earth.
We are particularly interested in understanding the evolution of the stress field in the interactions at plate boundaries, such as subduction zones and transform faults.
To this end, we use elasticity theory to find solutions to problems involving the interaction between tectonic plates and the underlying mantle.
However, addressing these issues analytically requires simplifying assumptions about the geometry of the system and the mechanical properties of the materials involved.
When studying the mechanics of boundary layers, an important simplifying assumption is that their behavior can be treated as if they were composed of thin elastic shells.
These shells have been proven to closely approximate more realistic plate boundary models, as they allow for rapid computation of the stress field within them.
For example, Figure 1 shows a comparison between the predictions obtained using a simple spherical shell model and those generated by the finite element model of the San Andreas Fault system.
Figure 1: Comparison of predicted displacements along the San Andreas Fault calculated using the spherical shell model (blue line) and the finite element model (red dots).

We conducted neutron powder diffraction experiments on the metal intercompound Sm2IrIn8 to determine its magnetic structure and compared it with the magnetic structure proposed for another member of this series of compounds, YbMgGaO4.
The results show that Sm2IrIn8 has antiferromagnetic ordering at TN = 3.5 K, with the magnetic moments aligned along the c-axis.

This is similar to the previous findings on YbMgGaO4, but is different from the theoretical predictions based on band structure calculations, which suggest that the ordered magnetic moments should be perpendicular to the c-axis.
We also found evidence of a structural phase transition occurring near T* ~ 80 K, at which point both the lattice parameters and the unit cell volume changed.
These results suggest that the low-temperature crystal structure may not completely align with the theoretically predicted high-temperature tetragonal symmetry.
Ultimately, we presented the specific heat data, which revealed significant anomalies associated with magnetic ordering and structural phase transitions.

Using density functional theory under the generalized gradient approximation, the electronic structure, equilibrium geometric shape, and finite temperature properties of sodium clusters containing 39 to 55 atoms have been investigated.
The results indicate that, except for Na_55, the ground states always have C_sv symmetry, while the minimum energy configuration of Na_55 has D_5h symmetry.
For all these clusters, we found that their structural parameters (such as bond lengths, bond angles, and dihedral angles) exhibit parity effects.
We also studied the vibrational frequencies and infrared intensities of these clusters at room temperature.
It has been proven that these calculated values are very consistent with the experimentally measured values.
Finally, we studied the thermodynamic stability of these clusters.
Our calculations indicate that most of them have a high melting point, but some of them may be unstable and prone to dissociating into smaller fragments.
Keywords: sodium cluster, electronic structure, vibration frequency, infrared intensity.

We suggest that the high-energy (HE) component in the gamma-ray burst (GRB) spectrum is produced by inverse Compton scattering between relativistic electrons accelerated in internal shocks and soft photons that are emitted during the prompt phase.
We demonstrate that this model can explain the high-energy spectral shapes and their temporal evolution of several outbursts observed by Fermi/LAT.
The predicted light curve is consistent with the measurements from Swift/BAT and Fermi/GBM.
This scenario also naturally explains why some outbursts emit bright optical flashes but have no detectable high-energy emissions.
Finally, we discussed how our results can be used to constrain the physical parameters of GRBs, such as their overall Lorentz factor or magnetic field strength.

We propose that the high-energy component in the GRB spectrum may be produced by the inverse Compton scattering between relativistic electrons accelerated in internal shocks and the soft photon field emitted during the prompt phase.
We indicate that this model correctly predicts the spectral shapes and temporal evolution of many bursts detected by Fermi LAT.
This naturally explains why high-energy (HE) emissions were not detected in some outbursts that exhibited bright optical flashes.
Our results indicate that future observations will allow us to determine important characteristics of gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), such as their overall Lorentz factor or magnetic field strength.

We conducted a morphological analysis of a sample of luminous compact galaxies (LCGs) selected from the Hubble Ultra Deep Field, which were studied using the Advanced Camera for Surveys on the Hubble Space Telescope.

We used GALFIT to fit a single Sérsic profile to all objects, allowing us to derive their structural parameters, such as effective radius \( R_e \), Sérsic index \( n \), axis ratio \( q \), position angle \( PA \), total magnitude \( m_T \), and half-light surface brightness \( SB_e \).
The results show that most of these galaxies are predominantly expanding bodies, with a high central concentration index (n > 2).
Additionally, we found that there is no significant correlation between the brightness or size of galaxies and their Sérsic index.

Finally, by comparing our results with those of other samples of massive early-type galaxies obtained at different redshifts, we conclude that the sizes of low-luminosity galaxies (LCGs) are similar, but their concentration is higher than that of local elliptical galaxies.

We present the results of an optical spectroscopy survey that aimed to identify candidates for tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs) from a sample of ultraluminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs).

We study the statistical properties of dark matter halos simulated in cosmological N-body simulations, with a focus on their shapes and relative orientations.
We found that for dark halo pairs separated by less than one Bohr radius, these quantities become highly correlated (the density in this region remains roughly constant).
This correlation still exists even when we only consider the paired cases where the distances are separate and exceed the line of sight between them.
These correlations can be understood as a result of the tidal forces exerted by adjacent halos.
Specifically, we demonstrate that the distribution of halo shapes is very sensitive to whether they are close to the symmetry axis of the local gravitational potential field.
Finally, we compare our results with the observations of galaxy clusters obtained using weak lensing techniques.
Our analysis indicates that the observed morphology of galaxy clusters may provide useful constraints on the nature of primordial fluctuations that led to structure formation in the universe.

We propose an algorithm for reconstructing a signal network, in which each node is associated with multiple time series data, and we assume that at any given point in time, only certain nodes are observed.
The proposed method consists of two steps: (1) estimating the state vector by solving a sparse reconstruction problem; (2) using the estimated state as features to infer the edge set.

Our numerical experiments on synthetic networks show that even with only partial information about the system available, our method can still accurately recover the structure and parameters of the underlying network.
Our results also indicate that the performance of the proposed method largely depends on the ability of the observation matrix to capture the sparse patterns of the true signal.
Finally, we applied this method to analyze the dynamic changes in protein phosphorylation in yeast cells under heat shock stress.
In particular, we have identified several key proteins that are involved in regulating the reaction process.

We study anonymous systems that operate in unstructured networks, such as Tor and Mixminion.
We demonstrate how to construct a hybrid that has provable guarantees against traffic analysis attacks using only local information about the underlying network topology.
Our design is based on mixing group users together at each node as users pass through the system.
This method allows us to achieve a high level of anonymity while maintaining low latency for most messages.
In addition, we proposed several extensions to the basic plan to make it easier to deploy in practical applications.
Finally, we conducted analysis and experimental evaluation of our system, which showed that it performs well under real-world conditions.
An anonymous system is used to protect users' privacy when sending or receiving data over public communication channels.
These systems usually consist of a group of nodes (referred to as hybrid nodes) that are interconnected through some form of anonymous communication channel.
Every message that enters the system undergoes multiple encryptions before being resent; this process is called "mixing."
The goal of these systems is to prevent attackers from linking the message sender and receiver within the system.
However, if all messages go through the exact same mixing sequence, they can still be correlated through a statistical technique called "traffic analysis."
Traffic analysis has shown that it could endanger the security of many existing anonymous systems, including Tor and Crowds.

This result suggests that cosmic rays may play an important role in regulating cluster dynamics on a large scale.
In addition, we will combine our results with those obtained previously from the Suzaku X-ray telescope to constrain the proportion of non-thermal pressure support in galaxy clusters.
Our analysis indicates that within r500, the contribution of cosmic rays to the total pressure can reach 30%-40%, while beyond 2r500, it drops to below 10%.
Finally, we discuss how these findings affect the dark matter annihilation cross-section limits derived from observations of galaxy clusters.

We reported the rapid diffusion of dipole ordering in liquid crystals, which leads to an enhanced nuclear spin-lattice relaxation rate, thereby achieving a higher degree of dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP).

The DNP effect was studied using electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy at X-band frequencies, employing a custom-built high-field spectrometer equipped with a commercial microwave bridge operating at 2.5 GHz.
We found that as we approach the nematic-isotropic phase transition temperature TNI = 35 °C, the enhancement factor significantly increases.
This finding can be explained by the hypothesis that molecular mobility decreases rapidly as it approaches TNI.
In addition to this observation, we found that the maximum achievable enhancement factor largely depends on the geometric shape of the sample.
For samples with thickness \( d < 1 \)
"Well, its value can reach 100 times greater than the values observed in thick samples."
These results are very important for the application of DNP in future NMR experiments conducted under extreme conditions, such as low temperatures or strong magnetic fields.
Quantum zero-knowledge proof is a quantum protocol that allows one party to prove its knowledge of certain secret information without revealing any other information about that information.
In this work, we study the general properties of these proofs and demonstrate how to use them to construct efficient quantum authentication schemes to ensure the security of classical information.

We also demonstrated several applications of our results, including the construction of a new quantum key distribution (QKD) system with unconditional security against collective attacks, as well as an improved QKD system based on weak coherent pulses.
Finally, we discussed the possible extension of our results in more practical scenarios, where the communication between Alice and Bob is not perfect, but rather has more noise or losses.
Quantum zero-knowledge proofs were proposed by Weisner.

These proofs are quantum protocols that allow one party (called Alice) to convince another party (called Bob) that she knows certain secret information while keeping her secrets hidden.

More formally, let us consider an interaction protocol between Alice and Bob, which consists of two phases: the first phase comprises a series of rounds in which Alice sends qubits to Bob, and Bob measures them according to his choice of measurement basis.
At the end of each round, Bob will publicly announce whether he accepts or rejects the status received.
If Bob accepts at least half of the statuses sent by Alice, then the second phase begins; otherwise, the protocol ends in the current round.
In the second stage, Alice revealed her secret to Bob after he had attained a sufficient state in the previous stage.
Otherwise, both parties will terminate the agreement.
It was proved in [4] that such a proof system exists if and only if there are one-way functions.
However, to date, there is no known explicit construction of such a proof.
We propose a graph isomorphism problem (GIP) solving algorithm based on quantum walk and Grover's search algorithm.
The proposed method is inspired by traditional random walk algorithms, but it uses the Grover operator instead of the Hadamard matrix to expedite the process.
We demonstrated how to use this new technology to solve the GIP problem with a high probability when the number of vertices in the two graphs is equal or differs by at most one unit.
Finally, we will compare our results with other advanced methods.
In recent years, there has been a growing interest in developing effective solutions to address problems related to computational complexity theory, such as the graph isomorphism problem.
The content of this question is to determine whether two given graphs are isomorphic; that is, whether they have the same structure irrespective of their labels.
The classic approach to solving GIP often relies on a combination of random walk techniques and some heuristic methods.
However, these methods require exponential time in the worst case.
On the other hand, quantum algorithms provide polynomial-time solutions for many NP-complete problems (including GIP).
The algorithm utilizes the principle of superposition, enabling it to explore all possible states simultaneously.
For example, the Shor algorithm solves integer factorization in polynomial time, while Grover's search algorithm finds any item in a database in quadratic time.

The equivalence principle is one of the most important concepts in general relativity. It states that all locally indistinguishable solutions that are physically equivalent to Einstein's field equations cannot be distinguished from one another.

In this article, we demonstrate how to extend the concept to three dimensions by considering the exact solutions of two different classes of vacuum Einstein field equations (with a cosmological constant).

The first category includes spatially homogeneous Bianchi IX models, which have been widely studied over the years as potential candidates for describing the early state of our universe, when its geometric shape was close to flat.
We prove that if the spatial volume forms of these models are symbolically the same, then they are globally diffeomorphic (homeomorphic).
This article demonstrates how to extend the concept of local physical equivalence between solutions of the Einstein field equations to three-dimensional space.

The sample consists of all known FRII-type radio galaxies with a redshift less than 0.1, an angular size greater than 10 arcseconds, and excludes those objects that are too close to bright background sources or other nearby radio galaxies.

These may represent the final stages of evolution before nuclear activity completely ceases.

Finally, we present new observations of two well-studied dying radio galaxies, 3C31 and NGC315, showing that they continue to evolve over time.
We study the dynamics of string cosmology with non-trivial string field potentials, focusing on their chaotic behavior.
We state that for certain categories of potential energy, there are regions where trajectories can be trapped by unstable fixed points or periodic orbits.

The existence of such attractor solutions may have an important impact on the evolution of our universe.
For example, this may explain why the present value of H(t) differs so greatly from its initial value at t = 0.

The Chandra X-ray Observatory has been observing the supernova remnant (SNR) produced by SN1987A in the Large Magellanic Cloud for over a decade, providing us with an unprecedented perspective on this young and vibrant astronomical object.
These observational results indicate that the shock wave is interacting with the dense interstellar material surrounding the progenitor star at speeds of up to 1000 kilometers per second.
This interaction produces bright emission points, manifested as moving outward in the debris shell.
These nodes appear to be primarily composed of oxygen-rich ejecta mixed with shocked interstellar gas.
Additionally, it seems that a large amount of hot plasma is trapped in front of the forward shock wave.
We present new results based on our analysis of the data obtained during the first year of the Chandra mission.

We presented the results of the neutrino mixing angles, CP-violating phases, and mass squared differences obtained by generating charged fermion masses through the Fritzsch ansatz in the context of SO(10) based extended supersymmetric grand unified theories.

We found that this model requires only one degree of freedom to fit all experimental data, and this parameter is related to the ratio between the two vacuum expectation values of the Higgs fields responsible for breaking the Pati-Salam gauge symmetry down to the standard model gauge group.
The CKM matrix elements have been predicted, along with the prediction of the Majorana phase related to lepton CP violation.
In addition, we demonstrate how the triple-two-fold pattern observed experimentally in the lepton sector naturally arises when the quark-lepton unification hypothesis is applied at high energy.
Finally, we briefly discuss some phenomenological consequences of our proposal, such as neutrinoless double beta decay and proton decay.

We present new astrometric results for the candidate exoplanetary companion HD 33636, obtained through the Fine Guidance Sensor (FGS) on the Hubble Space Telescope (HST).
These data were combined with previously published radial velocity measurements to determine the mass of the object.
We found that this is likely an M dwarf star, with a mass between 0.3 to 1.0 times that of Jupiter.
The orbital parameters derived here are very consistent with the parameters determined using different techniques previously.
This system may be similar to the state of our own solar system during its early formation, when planets were still forming around a young star.
Keywords: Exoplanets - Astrometry - Radial Velocity - Hubble Space Telescope - Mass Measurement - HD 33636.
Introduction: The detection of transiting giant planets has been one of the major achievements of modern astronomy in the past decade.
However, among all known planetary systems, only about 10% contain such massive objects.
Most of these were discovered through high-precision Doppler spectroscopy or direct imaging methods.
In contrast, so far, very few low-mass companions have been discovered, as they produce less reflex motion and/or are dimmer than higher-mass companions.
Therefore, there is a significant gap in the mass distribution of known exoplanets, ranging from several Earth masses to masses similar to that of Neptune.
Therefore, searching for low-quality companions is very important, as they can provide valuable information about the formation process of planetary systems.
One possible method for detecting low-quality companions is to use high angular resolution observations made by space telescopes like the Hubble Space Telescope (HST).
Such observations allow us to measure the position angle of the host star relative to its nearby neighbors.
If we assume that the observed motion is solely due to the gravitational interaction with another celestial body, then we can derive the expected distance and position angle of the companion star.
By combining these results with simultaneous precise radial velocity measurements, we can obtain the complete three-dimensional orbit of the companion star, allowing us to calculate its mass.
We present the spectral index distribution (SID) of blazars detected by the Energetic Gamma Ray Experiment Telescope (EGRET).
The SID is obtained through two different methods, and we found that these two methods yield consistent results within the range of statistical error.
We will compare our results with previous studies that were based on smaller samples or limited energy ranges.
Our sample includes all "quasar candidate" sources listed in the third edition of the EGRET catalog (3EG), totaling 157 objects.

In addition to these three 3EG blazars, we have also included four BL Lacertae objects, whose radio characteristics are similar to those of known blazars, but which were not included in previous studies due to not being detected at high energies.
These additional sources were discovered through a cross-correlation between the Véron-Cetty and Véron active galactic nuclei catalog and the NRAO VLA sky survey.

Using this merged sample composed of 161 quasars, we calculate the ratio of flat-spectrum quasars (similar to FSRQs) to steep-spectrum quasars (similar to BL Lacs) among the total quasars observed by EGRET.
This score largely depends on the assumed high-energy cutoff value E_cutoff.

For example, if we assume E_cutoff = 10 GeV, then blazars similar to FSRQs account for about 80% of the entire sample; however, if we use a very low value, such as 1 MeV, only 20% of the blazars can be classified as similar to FSRQs.
The influence of oxygen vacancies (V) on the magnetic properties of titanium dioxide was studied using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Mössbauer spectroscopy, and magnetization measurements.
The results show that V can induce ferromagnetic ordering at room temperature, with an effective magnetic moment of 1.6 μB per chemical formula unit.
This is attributed to the formation of small clusters of V ions, which are antiferromagnetically coupled through superexchange interactions between adjacent O-2p orbitals.
These findings provide new insights into the origins of ferromagnetism observed in some transition metal oxides.
Titanium dioxide, due to its high reactivity and stability, has been widely used as a photocatalyst for water splitting under visible light irradiation.

The driving mechanism of jets and outflows remains an unresolved mystery, especially when the jet/outflow source does not have a clear central engine, such as a black hole or a protostar.
In this work, we propose that magnetic reconnection may be the cause of jet emissions and outflows of material during the star formation process.
We indicate that magnetic reconnection can efficiently accelerate particles to relativistic energies through Fermi acceleration in shock waves driven by reconnection outflows.
Accelerating electrons will generate synchrotron radiation, which may explain the radio observations of jets and outflows.
In addition, the high-energy protons generated in the strong cooling storage ring (RCS) also contribute to non-thermal radiation through anti-Compton scattering with background photons.
Finally, we discussed how our model explains some observational features of jets and outflows.
Keywords: magnetic reconnection; jet; particle acceleration; shock; synchrotron radiation; non-thermal radiation

We present new observational results of the intervening metal systems associated with gamma-ray burst (GRB) 050525A at a redshift range of z ~ 1.5-2.0, which is one of only two gamma-ray bursts with a spectroscopic redshift currently known.

In the past few decades, the study of galaxy clusters has played an important role in our understanding of cosmology.
In fact, it was through the observation of galaxy clusters that we first discovered evidence supporting the existence of non-baryonic dark matter.

Today, galaxy clusters are still widely used to test theories of structure formation [2], and they provide important constraints on cosmological parameters, such as the Hubble constant [3] and the equation of state parameter w [4].
However, despite achieving many successes, there are still several unresolved questions about galaxy clusters that have yet to receive satisfactory answers.

For example, although current observation technologies can accurately measure the total light emitted by a galaxy cluster, it is still difficult to determine how much of this light comes from the stars within individual galaxies compared to the diffuse gas located outside the galaxies.

Similarly, although we can estimate the total gravitational mass of a galaxy cluster with relative accuracy using various methods, it remains unclear how much of that mass is associated with visible objects such as galaxies.

We introduce the concept of Generalized Conditional Random Fields (GCRFs) and demonstrate how they can be used to model arbitrary probability distributions for structured datasets (such as sequences or trees).
We proposed an efficient algorithm to learn the GCRF parameters by performing gradient descent on the log-likelihood objective function.

Conditional Random Fields (CRFs) (Lafferty et al., 2001) are an undirected graphical model that has been successfully applied to many sequence data-related problems, such as (Sha & Pereira, 2003).

According to this work, we propose Generalized Conditional Random Fields (GCRFs), which is a generalization of conditional random fields that allows us to represent any distribution over structured datasets such as sequences or trees.
The key idea of GCRF is to use a set of latent variables to capture the dependencies between different parts of the input space.
This allows us to efficiently compute the partition function required for standard conditional random fields using dynamic programming techniques.
In addition, this also enables the use of methods similar to Maximum Entropy Markov Models (MEMMs) to train GCRFs in a gradient-based manner.
To evaluate the performance of our method, we applied it to two important applications: part-of-speech tagging.

We consider a sparse multipath channel with random delays, where each path is modeled as an independent Rayleigh fading channel.
We derived the exact expressions for the ergodic capacity and the outage probability of these channels in the wideband regime (i.e., when the bandwidth approaches infinity).
Our results indicate that the traversal capacity and interruptions are determined by the number of paths N, their average power Pn = E{|hn(t)|2}, and the delay spread T.

Specifically, we found that when the signal-to-noise ratio is high, if \( N > \frac{2W}{\pi T} \) or \( N < \frac{4W}{\pi T} \), the traversal capacity has a linear relationship with the bandwidth \( W \); otherwise, it decreases only polynomially.
Finally, the numerical examples demonstrate how these scaling laws depend on various system parameters.
We present the results of an X-ray study of the supernova remnant (SNR) G299.2-2.9 using data obtained from the Chandra and XMM-Newton observatories.
The supernova remnant is located in the constellation Canis Minor, about 5,000 parsecs away, which corresponds to an angular size of approximately 30 arcminutes.
We found that the spectrum of the object can be described using two thermal components, with temperatures T1 = 7×10^6 K and T2 = 2×10^6 K.
Through addition, we detected non-thermal radiation above 10 keV. Using these parameters, we estimate the age of the supernova remnant to be t = 4000 years.
This value is in good agreement with the characteristic time of the shell's expansion into the surrounding medium.
Based on our analysis, we conclude that the observed morphology of the supernova remnant is consistent with a spherical explosion model expanding outward in a uniform interstellar medium.
The Chip Network (NoC) is an emerging interconnection paradigm used to interconnect a large number of processing units in parallel computing systems.

In future multi-core and many-core processors, network-on-chip (NoC) is expected to become the dominant communication infrastructure, which will require high bandwidth and low latency communication between cores.
However, traditional electrical networks-on-chip (NoCs) face power consumption issues due to their limited scalability when the number of cores increases.
In this work, we propose a novel bio-inspired optical network-on-chip (NoC) architecture that can provide higher bandwidth than traditional electrical network chips with lower energy consumption.
The proposed network-on-chip (NoC) consists of two main components: a photonic router and a optoelectronic transceiver.
Photon routers use silicon photonic technology to route packets simultaneously across multiple channels through wavelength division multiplexing.
The optoelectronic transceiver uses a vertical cavity surface emitting laser diode as the transmitter and an avalanche photodiode as the receiver.

We developed a detailed simulation model based on SystemC to evaluate the performance characteristics of our proposed network-on-chip (NoC) design, such as packet delay, throughput, and power consumption.

Our research findings indicate that the proposed network-on-chip (NoC) provides up to four times the bandwidth per unit area while consuming less power, outperforming existing electrical network chips.
Keywords: Chip-scale optical networks, silicon photonics
We study the elasticity of thin films with periodic microstructures that are constrained on a substrate.
We have demonstrated that such a system can exhibit extraordinarily large Young's modulus and Poisson's ratio.
The origin of these effects can be traced back to the existence of phonon soft modes associated with the periodicity in the direction of the film normal.
These results are of great significance for designing innovative materials with specific elastic properties.
In recent years, people have become increasingly concerned about how confinement affects the physical behavior of materials at the nanoscale.

This will be one of the most spectacular events humanity has ever witnessed.

In this presentation, I will describe how we utilize observations from ground telescopes and space observatories like the Hubble Space Telescope to study these collisions, and gain insights into dark matter, galaxies, stars, black holes, and other cosmic phenomena that make up our universe.
