We reported the discovery of an unexpected ring-shaped dark matter structure at the center of the galaxy cluster CL0024+17, which is located approximately 3 billion light-years away from Earth and has been extensively studied using various observational techniques, including gravitational lensing.

The mass distribution inferred from strong gravitational lensing shows two massive subclusters that are 1 Mpc (3 arcminutes) apart, with a total mass of 2 x 10¹⁵ h⁻¹M₊ within a central radius of 0.5h⁻¹Mpc.
We found that this binary star cluster system can be well described as a binary merger model, where each component consists of three parts: a main halo and two smaller halos surrounding it.

In addition to these six galaxy clusters, we also found another smaller galaxy cluster near the center of the merging system, located at a position that coincides with the peak of X-ray radiation observed by the Chandra satellite.

We report high-resolution observations using the PACS (Poglitsch et al., 2010) and SPIRE (Griffin et al., 2010) instruments aboard the Herschel Space Telescope, which for the first time revealed the presence of cold dust emission at temperatures as low as T = 20 K in two nearby ultraluminous infrared galaxies (ULIRGs), Arp 220 and Mrk 231.
The observed flux is consistent with the predictions of starburst models based on heating by young stars.
We found evidence suggesting the existence of an additional colder dust component, which may be related to the obscured active galactic nucleus (AGN) activity present in these celestial bodies.
In addition, we detected the [CII] 158 µm spectral line using PACS spectroscopy in two sources.
This allows us to estimate the total mass of warm molecular hydrogen, M(H2).
For Arp 220, this is equivalent to a mass of 1.5 x 10^9 solar masses within a radius of 100 pc around the core.

We provide new photometric and spectral observational data for the two stars HD 122563 (=HR 5171A) and BD+17°3248, which are suspected to be members of the intermediate-age group of helium-rich giants proposed in the globular cluster Omega Centauri.

We found that the atmospheric parameters of these two stars are very similar to the results of previous studies of other candidate helium-rich giants in the Large Magellanic Cloud: effective temperature T eff = 8200 K; logarithmic gravity log g = 3.8; iron abundance [Fe/H] = -1.0 dex.
The observed spectrum does not show evidence of He II lines at 4686 Å or 5412 Å, but it does display strong Balmer line emission, with equivalent widths ranging from -40 to -50 mÅ.
These results suggest that these stars may actually not belong to the proposed category of objects.
However, based solely on our current dataset, we cannot rule out the possibility that they are indeed helium-rich giants.
We present new ultraviolet spectra of four Lyman break galaxies (LBGs) with redshifts between 5 and 6, which were obtained using the ultraviolet spectrograph on the Hubble Space Telescope.
These data are used to measure the interstellar medium properties of these celestial objects by fitting a model to the observed absorption line profiles.
We found that the metallicity of all four LBGs is very high, ranging from 0.2 times solar to 1 time solar, which is consistent with previous results based on optical spectra.
In addition, we detected strong outflows in the three targets, as evidenced by the blueshifted interstellar absorption lines.
These observations suggest that massive stars may have been responsible for driving galactic-scale winds before the completion of reionization.
This work was funded by NASA under grant number HST-GO-10775.01-A, provided by the Space Telescope Science Institute, which operates under the AURA contract NAS5-26555 with NASA.
We present an analysis of deep observations from the Chandra X-ray Observatory of two high-redshift galaxies, MS1512-cB58 and APM 08279+5255 (z = 3.91).
We found that both sources exhibit extended soft X-ray emission, with a brightness exceeding 10^43 erg/second.
The observed characteristics are consistent with those expected from supernova-driven or active nucleus-driven galactic winds.

In addition to these diffuse components, we detected several point-like X-ray sources in the field of view of each galaxy, which may be associated with young supermassive black holes at early formation stages.

The full-band luminosity range of these celestial bodies is between \(10^{44}\) and \(10^{46}\) joules per second, and they seem to follow a trajectory similar to that of quasars in cosmic time evolution.
This work is based on data obtained from the guaranteed observing time program operated by NASA under contract NAS8-39073.

Erbium-doped fiber amplifiers (EDFA) have been widely used in communication and sensing applications due to their high gain, low noise figure, broad bandwidth, and compatibility with silicate optical fibers.
However, EDFA has some disadvantages, such as high cost and limited lifespan, because they require expensive rare earth elements, such as erbium ions.

After this research, we reported the preparation of a new type of glass-ceramic material based on sodium chloride and potassium chloride phosphates, which was produced through a melting-quenching method and contains different concentrations of Er3+ ions.
The structural characterization was performed using X-ray powder diffraction analysis (XRPD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS).
At room temperature, the optical absorption spectrum is recorded between 300 nm and 1600 nm.
The photoluminescence emission measurements were conducted at an excitation wavelength of 980 nanometers.
The study found that the prepared samples exhibit good transparency over a wide wavelength range (up to 1600 nanometers).

We have detected absorption lines for the first time in the rest-frame ultraviolet spectra of two galaxies at redshifts z = 2.3 and 3.1, which may be related to outflows driven by star formation activities.
The observational characteristics of these winds are consistent with the predictions for massive star-forming galaxies (M > 10^10 M⊙) at similar redshifts.
We also found evidence indicating that the speed of these gases was accelerated to as much as 1000 kilometers per second.
These results suggest that this wind may play an important role in the evolution of galaxies over cosmic time.
Keywords: Galaxy evolution; star formation; winds. Galaxies evolve through the merging and interactions between their composed dark matter halos and baryonic components.
Through accumulation, they grow by adding material to the existing structure or by forming new ones within it.
However, it is currently unclear how this growth occurs on a small scale.
Recent observations indicate that many nearby galaxies contain supermassive black holes surrounded by dense gas disks.
Some suggest that the feedback processes from the jets and/or winds produced by active galactic nuclei can regulate the growth of central black holes and their host galaxies.

The process can explain why most galaxies do not appear to contain supermassive black holes, as the mass of these black holes exceeds the upper limit set by the relationship between black hole mass and bulge velocity dispersion.
We present the asymmetric observational results of the Mg II k line during flares and compare them with the numerical simulation results obtained using the RH code (Uitenbroek 2001).
The observed contours indicate that the blue wing is enhanced at all heights above the limb where we can see the flare emission, relative to the red wing.
This effect is more pronounced at higher altitudes.
We found that this behavior cannot be explained solely by the Doppler shift caused by massive plasma motion along the line of sight (LOS).
In addition, our model shows that if the non-thermal electron beam is not included as an additional heating source, the observed profile shape cannot be reproduced.
Keywords: solar flares, chromospheric lines, non-thermal electrons, radiative fluid dynamics model, RH code, Mg II k line, linear polarization asymmetry.

1 Introduction  
The intense release of energy during solar flares leads to rapid changes in the physical conditions of the solar atmosphere.
These include temperature increases of several million kelvins, strong magnetic fields, high density, and large velocities.
All these factors affect the shape of the spectral lines emitted from different atmospheric layers.

For example, it has been proven that the intensity ratio between two Fe I spectral lines formed at different temperatures depends on the formation height of each spectral line (Feldman et al., 1995; Brosius & Phillips, 2004).

In addition, the presence of non-thermal electrons leads to a significant deviation from the Maxwell velocity distribution, resulting in asymmetric spectral line profiles (e.g., Canfield et al. (1990); Doschek et al. (1991)). Meanwhile, the overall flow causes a Doppler shift in the central position of the spectral lines (Doschek et al., 1991; Brosius & Phillips 2004; Brosius 2009).
Therefore, studying the time evolution of linear profiles provides us with important information about the dynamics of flare regions.
However, interpreting these data requires a detailed understanding of the fundamental physics behind the processes that lead to the observed phenomena.
In particular, the study of the Mg II h&k lines provides a unique opportunity to investigate various aspects of solar flares, as they form over a wide range.

We report the absorption spectrum of isolated single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) obtained in solution, which was acquired using scanning near-field optical microscopy with sub-wavelength resolution.
SWNTs are suspended between two gold electrodes and illuminated by one electrode at normal incidence to excite transverse electric (TE) and transverse magnetic (TM) polarized light.
We observed that due to the presence of metal tubes in the sample, the TE mode is strongly suppressed compared to the TM polarization.
This effect can be used as a spectral tool for identifying the chirality of individual single-walled carbon nanotubes.
Single-walled carbon nanotubes have attracted considerable attention due to their unique electronic properties, which are sensitive to their diameter and chirality angle.
